Ruth is a farmer in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where she has been in business for more than 10 years. Her primary source of income is milk, maize and bean production, but she also sells clothes to earn extra money. She knows that challenges always exist, and currently her main one is marketing her products and dealing with competition.

Ruth has applied for a loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 60,000 to diversity her farm by raising poultry. She says that with this loan she will have a higher income, be better able to support her family and do a better job of coping with high prices. She hopes to expand her business in the future and acquire more poultry so that she can meet the high demand for this product in her area, especially during the festival seasons.

loans.use: To start a poultry-raising business

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun Non and her husband, Mr. Sorn Chhin, live along National Road Number Five, about 18 kilometers outside of Phnom Penh, Cambodia. They have been married since 1993 and have three children, two sons and one daughter. Thoeun sells fruit in front of a factory. Her husband has been a hairdresser since he was young. In addition, he also grows rice in the village. The road on which their house is located is too small and carries very heavy traffic. Thoeun has applied for a loan for $500 to move the building farther away from the road.

loans.use: To move her house away from a road that is small and very busy.

loans.name: Tashboy

texts.ru: Тавкиев Ташбой проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 53 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Более 20 лет занимается животноводством. Покупает телят, откармливает и продает на рынке. Одновременно занимается растениеводством. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа скота.
texts.en:
Tashboy T. lives in the J. Rumy district. He is 53 years old, married and has 4 children. He has a secondary education. Tashboy has been involved in animal husbandry for over 20 years. He buys calves, fattens and sells them at a market. At the same time, he is involved in agriculture. His wife helps him with this business. Tashboy is requesting the loan to buy livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Mrs. Sophal Khieng Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group, which is made up of residents of Daeum Doung village in Takeo province, has come together to apply for a loan which its members will use for many different purposes. Mrs. Sophal K. is a village bank president who has been chosen by the members to lead this group. She makes a living selling rice, and because business is good she has decided to apply for a loan to expand her small company. Her husband, Mr. Yin Voeurn, helps her acquire and sell rice. Mrs. Sophal K. is 43 years old and the mother of two children, both of whom attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice for resale

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Mrs. Airene P. is a 30-year-old married woman with three children. She lives in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur with her family and makes a living growing rice on her one-hectare field. She and her husband till the soil together, spending most of their time at the farm because they want to make it productive and save for their children’s future.

Airene has started planting her next crop but needs additional supplies. She has applied for a loan for PHP 11,000 from CEVI  to buy seeds, fertilizer and other items.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en: Brenda is 26 years old and earns a living by farming. She is married and has two children, the older of which is seven.  She works hard to feed her family and save for her children’s future, spending most of the day tilling her land to ensure that it is productive. She needs to buy supplies such as fertilizer and seeds for her farm, and has applied for a loan for PHP 11,000 to make these purchases possible.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia, 42 years old, is a rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She is married with seven children and her oldest child is aged 20 and goes to school.

Julia is involved in rice farming. She works hard to be able to keep up with the growing needs in her household. She hopes to send all her children to school and have them finish college.

Julia needs financing for her farm. She lacks farm inputs like seed and fertilizer. She is requesting a loan of Php 14,000 which she will use to acquire the farm inputs she needs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Seab

texts.en:
Mr. Seab N., age 53, and his wife, Mrs. Meun Hor, age 52, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1970 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. All of their daughters weave silk at home and the sons attend school. His wife stays at home and does housework.

Seab has been raising chickens for one month. He is requesting his first loan of $1,200 to use for his chicken business.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for his business

loans.name: Lory

texts.en:
Lory farms for a living. She is 30 years old and is married with three children; her oldest child is aged 10. She dreams of having all her children graduate from college and find decent jobs for themselves.

Lory spends her daytime maintaining the farm, making sure it will be productive. Like other farmers, she wants to grow her farm so she would also earn more.

Lory said that she and her husband are now preparing their farm for planting. She needs farm inputs for it such as seed, fertilizer and other items. She asked for a loan from CEVI of Php 14,000 which she would use to acquire the farm inputs.

Receiving this loan will be truly helpful to Lory’s goal of being productive.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
Lani is a married, 42-year-old woman living with her husband and children. She lives in the town of Hikkaduwa. Her husband operates a transport service for employment.

Lani prepares food to be sold to local shops and markets, which helps to support her family's expenses. Every day, her husband goes to small restaurants to help sell her food.

Two years ago Lani started this business. She is a very hardworking, active and honest lady and she hopes to continue to see success.

Lani has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to buy supplies for her food-preparation business. Ultimately she hopes to use her increased income to renovate her family's house.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies for food preparation

loans.name: Norie

texts.en:
Norie is thankful she has a farm to till. It is what her family depends on for food, clothes and their other needs.

At 52, Norie now has five children with her husband Percival. Like other mothers, she only wants the best for her children. She helps her husband till their farm to keep up with her family’s increasing needs. She chose to plant rice crops because it is a basic need among Filipino homes, thus easier to sell.

Norie currently needs inputs for her rice farm. She applied for a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use it to acquire seed, fertilizer and other inputs. She would also be able to pay the laborers who helped work on her farm.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs and to pay laborers

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
“For the many years that I’ve worked at the farm, I’ve experienced a lot of difficulties but was still able to get through,” shares Ramon of his farming. He is 38 years old and has a six-year-old child.

Because of the hot weather, Ramon said that a lot of weeds are growing on his farm. He spends the whole day getting rid of the weeds abd making sure his rice crops can grow healthy on his land. He wants to double his harvest so he would also earn more and be able to save.

Ramon would like to request a loan of Php 11,000. which he will use it to supply his farm with seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
48-year-old Remedios is a married woman with seven children. Her oldest child is aged 23.

Remedios is involved in rice farming. She works hard to be able to provide for her family’s needs and send all her children to school. She hopes to have better living conditions.

Remedios’s rice farm is lacking inputs. She is seeking a loan of Php 10,000 which she will use to buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ricky

texts.en:
Ricky owns a farm and tills it himself. He is 30 years old and is married with two children. He lives in Agusan Del Sur with his family. He wants to take this opportunity to save for his young children’s future. He wants them to be given a proper education.

Ricky is in need of financial support for his farm. His farm lacks inputs like seed and fertilizer so he applied for a loan of Php 14,000 from CEVI to acquire these inputs. Having this loan would be truly helpful to Ricky’s farming.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Vibora

texts.en:
Vibora, a 36-year-old married woman, farms for a living. She has four children with the oldest aged 20.

Vibora patiently cultivates her farm in order to grow healthy rice crops. She said that her income from the farm helps a lot in providing for her family’s needs, especially her children’s education.

Vibora joined CEVI in 2008 hoping to obtain its financial services. She said that her previous loans were really helpful in maintaining her farm.

Vibora is now requesting Php 14,000, which she will use for her farm. She will buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Biodun

texts.en:
Biodun is a business-oriented woman. She produces cellophane bags (bags made of a thin, transparent sheet of regenerated cellulose) in her house and she supplies them to her numerous customers. She has been in the business for the past four years and has been able to retain many customers because she is customer-driven.

Biodun is 31 years of age. She is married with a kid and her husband is a transporter in Lagos State. She plays a very vital role in her family by feeding, clothing, and paying school fees for her children. She wants to have an additional business, the sale of drinks and sachet water (water in plastic bags), for additional income.

Biodun is presently asking for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase a deep freezer which she can use to cool her drinks and sachet water to sell. She is very grateful to Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer for her new business

loans.name: Mr. Kha Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, which consists of seventeen people, is located in Prey Rumdeng village in Takeo province and each member will use the loan for a different purpose.

Mr. Kha K. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. He is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare (5-acre) field on which he cultivates rice to earn a living.

In this farming, Kha K. faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to plow his rice field. So she decided to ask for a loan to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field. With the rest of the loan, he would buy recycling goods to re-sell for an income. His wife, Mrs. Keo Hon, buys recycling goods and resells them for a good price to support the family.

Mr. Kha K. has four children, three of whom are attending the local school while the other looks after a cow.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with two oxen to plow his field

loans.name: Niroshani

texts.en:
Niroshani is a married, 30-year-old woman living with her husband. She has two children, one of whom is 2 and the other is 6 months old.

Niroshani’s mother and sister help her to handle her business, which consists of making bricks which are then sold throughout her local town. She has been doing this activity for one year now.

Her husband has a government job, so she runs this brick-making business independently. She is a hardworking, active, and honest woman. She wants to be a self-sufficient woman some day, as she does not like to depend on other people.

Niroshani is seeking a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help expand her business and to purchase bricks.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase more bricks

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a 44 year-old single woman who lives in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale. She has two children ages 18 and 20 years old who attend school.

Esther has been a farmer for over thirteen years.  She sells a variety of products like maize, milk, eggs and hens at the local market.  She also sells timber. She says the main challenges to her business are poor transportation, falling prices and competition from other businessmen.

Esther has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo.  Previously she completing one loan of Kes. 30,000.  She now requested a loan of Kes. 46,200 to purchase and insure a dairy cow and to expand her poultry operation.  She says the extra income will help her family in many ways. She will be able to continue her children's education.  There will be enough milk and food for personal consumption and a surplus for selling.

Esther's main goal is to acquire two more dairy animals. She wants to sell milk to the Kenya Cooperative of Cremeries to have a stable source of income.

loans.use: Purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Duyen's Group

texts.en:
Duyen T. N. is 23 years old and lives in Xuan Non, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She is married with a small child.

Since Duyen’s family is quite young, Duyen has T. work hard T. scratch a living. At the moment, she owns a small grocery store serving the customers of the local community.

Joining SEDA micro-finance program in 2007, Duyen has been a dynamic, energetic and respected leader of a eight-member group. Even though her monthly income is rather unstabL. and not high at all (2,500,000 VND per month), she has always managed T. repay on time.

In the next round, she would like T. borrow 5,014,000 VND (approximately 270 USD) T. invest in her business. Hopefully, that will enabL. her T. increase her profit and therefore have more money T. provide for her child and send him T. school in the not-too-distant future.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Nguyệt Thị Nguyễn is 45 years old. She wants T. take out a loan of 5,014,000 VND (approximately 270 USD) sell fish in the local market. 

Hường Thị Nguyễn is a 34-year-old farmer. She needs T. borrow 4,142,000 VND (approximately 225 USD) T. buy feed for her poultry.

Giang Thị Tô is 26 years old. She also wants T. borrow 4,142,000 VND (approximately 225 USD) T. expand her business.

Dung Thị Tô is 47 years old. She would like T. take out a loan of 5,014,000 VND (approximately 270 USD) T. finance her plan T. raise poultry.

Diên T. Lê is also 47 years old. She wants T. borrow 4,142,000 VND (approximately 225 USD) T. invest in raising animals.

Vân Thị Nguyễn is 51 years old. She would like T. take out a loan of 5,014,000 VND (approximately 270 USD) T. make tofu.

Ý Thị Lê is 28 years old. She is requesting a loan of 4,142,000 VND (approximately 225 USD) T. raise ducks.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Kamukamu Kasambya Group

texts.en:
Jane is a 48-year-old woman living in Karuguuza, Uganda. She sells local brew and alcohol which has sustained her and her family.

Jane is the treasurer of her group called Kamukamu Kasambya which is based in Karuguuza, Uganda. The group has been in existence for five years and now has twenty-one active members who access credit from HOFOKAM. The group members deal in activities like poultry, restaurant, retail business, clothing, butchery, selling dry foods and cereals, and bar business.

In addition to selling local brew, Jane also farms to sustain her family requirements. She intends to use the loan to buy more local brew to sell.

Note: Jane is sitted at the centre forward in the group photo.

loans.use: To buy more local brew and alcohol to sell

loans.name: Mahmasharif

texts.ru: Холов Махмашариф проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 28 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Предоставляет услугу. У него цех, где он обрабатывает хлопок. Этой деятельностью занимается уже 8 лет. Кредит берет для покупки хлопка (сырья), чтобы обработать и продать.
texts.en:
Mahmasharif K. lives in the J. Rumi region. He is 28 years old. He is married and has four children. He has secondary education. He provides a service. He has a factory where he processes cotton. He has bee doing this business for eight years. He is taking out the loan to buy raw cotton to process and sell it.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw cotton

loans.name: Jobel

texts.en:
Jobel is a 41-year-old married man with three children. His oldest child is only nine years old, so he works hard to save for their future. He says school fees keep increasing. In 1994, Jobel started his Disco Mobile Rental.  He bought speakers and sound systems that he rents to other municipalities during fiestas and other events.  From his income and hard work, he was able to start his own welding shop that he hopes to expand upon.

Jobel has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. since 2007.  He said that his previous loans were helpful in improving his business. He is now requesting a loan Php 50,000.  He will use this loan to buy disco light and speakers.  He also plans to buy a welding machine, tools and an oxygen tank. 
--------------------------
“Asenso Loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop.  CEVI recognises the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress.  
CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills.  Please help us provide support for these clients”

“Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the past 5 years.  Based in Bohol, they have 22 branches throughout the Philippines, and will soon be adding two more branches.  CEVI has recently been awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  Social performance monitoring is imperative in order to measure a microfinance institute’s effectiveness.  The fact that CEVI is participating in this process speaks volumes.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings.  Please feel free to take a look at the CEVI Website”

loans.use: Buy speakers, Disco lights, welding machine and tools.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose sells groceries and foodstuffs. Her shop is opposite her house and this makes it very easy for her to access at any time of the day. She opens her shop early and closes late in the evening every day. She started this business seven years ago. She is very happy with her business because she is able to support her husband in taking care of the family.

Bose wants to expand her business by buying more groceries and foodstuffs to sell, as this attracts a discount, attracts more customers and improves her profit. She hopes for the loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell.

Bose is married with three children and she is 30 years old. The child with her in the photo is her youngest child who is two years old. Bose appreciates all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en: Despite misusing the previous loan she received for the needs of her family instead of her business, Michelle F. has been able to repay the whole amount on its expected due date. Her husband had been supporting her financially through his small income. Now, Michelle is again requesting a loan to be used to start another business, pig fattening. Michelle still plans to continue her food selling business and income from it will be used to support her family's needs and for her weekly payment to ASHI. After four months of fattening her pigs, profit from the business will be used to support her children's education until college and improve their standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening and selling

loans.name: Sêdé

texts.fr: H. Sêdé est née en 1968 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Cela fait déjà sept ans que Sêdé vit à Saint martin, un quartier de Cotonou. Mariée à HOUNSOU, Sêdé est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Sêdé n’a plus d’enfants à charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Sêdé seconde son mari pour s’acquitter des charges familiales. En effet, pour participer aux dépenses du foyer, Sêdé mène comme activité principale, la vente de poissons et de piments séchés. De façon secondaire, Sêdé vend des conserves de tomâtes. Sêdé achète et vend par la même occasion ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Sêdé n’a pas été à l’école mais possède quatre années d’expériences dans son domaine. Sêdé a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt chez ALIDé, prêt qui a été bien remboursé. Sêdé souhaite renforcer son activité mais ne dispose pas d’assez de ressources financières pour y arriver, c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
H. Sêdé was born in 1968 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  For seven years already, she has been living in Saint Martin, a district of Cotonou.  Married to HOUNSOU, she is the mother of two children, who have both had schooling.  She no long has children to support.  The couple live together with their children.  She backs up her husband in covering family expenses.  Basically, to take part in covering household expenses, Sêdé runs her main business selling fish and dried chili peppers.  Secondarily, she sells canned tomatoes.  She buys and sells these goods in the same trip to Dantokpa, the international market of Benin She did not attend school but has four years of experience in her domain.  She once benefited from a loan with ALIDé that she has repaid.  Sêdé wishes to bolster her business but lacks sufficient financial resources to do so.  This is why she is requesting a second loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fish and chili peppers

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 41 years old woman who operates a small food kiosk, selling ready-made food like fries, sausages, cakes, soft drinks and more.  Her food kiosk is situated next to the bus terminus at Kinoo trading center.  This is her primary business, which she has been doing for four years.  Her customers are mainly commuters and the retailers from the market. 

She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her fifth loan with KADET.  She has applied for a loan which she will use to relocate to a better and more spacious building.

Her business is still very young and small.  She hopes that with the extra profit from this loan she will be able to add more stock and grow substantially.

loans.use: Relocate her business to a larger space.

loans.name: Mrs. Khoeurn Phon Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group consists of ten people who live in Pun Phnum, in Takeo province.  Members will use their loan for different purposes.  KhO. P. was selected by the members to be the group president. She sells brooms. Her husband, Eourn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Although they work hard they still earn less income than they need to support their family.  KhO. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband so he can operate a motorbike taxi service.  KhO. is the mother of two children who attend a local school.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for her husband to operate a motorbike taxi service.

loans.name: Ruqaiya's Group

texts.en:
Ruqaiya is from the city Borewala, famous for its shrines in Pakistan. Ruqaiya is 35-year old, married and the mother of three children.  To make a living, Ruqaiya sews clothes.  She has been in business for over 6 years and earns approximately Pak Rs. 6,000 a month. 

Her husband works as an auto-rickshaw driver (three-wheeled motor vehicle) to generate income.  Ruqaiya is applying for a loan to repair his rickshaw.

loans.use: Repair a rickshaw.

loans.name: Yèyinou

texts.fr: Née en 1969 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, H. Yèyinou vit depuis 35 ans à Agbato, un quartier de Cotonou. Yèyinou est mariée à HOUNSA Grégoire avec qui elle a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Yèyinou n’a plus aucun enfant à sa charge. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Yèyinou et son mari partagent ensemble les dépenses familiales. Pour apporter sa part contributive, Yèyinou exerce comme activité, la vente de crevettes fumées. Yèyinou s’approvisionne sur le lac de Agbato. Yèyinou effectue la vente de ses produits à son domicile et également à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cela fait déjà 20 ans que Yèyinou mène cette activité, mais elle n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Yèyinou est une cliente fidèle de ALIDé car elle a déjà obtenu cinq crédits et ces crédits on tous été bien remboursés. Dans le souci constant de renforcer son activité, Yèyinou souhaite bénéficier d’un sixième prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1969 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. H. Yèyinou has been living for 35 years in Agbato, a district of Cotonou.  She is married to Mr. HOUNSA Grégoire, with whom she has three children, who all attended school.  She no longer has any children to support. The couple live together with their children.  Together, she and her husband share in covering household expenses.  As for her share, Yèyinou has a business selling smoked shrimp.  She gets her supplies from Agbato Lake.  She sells her goods out of her home and also at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has been in this business for twenty years already, but she has never attended school.  Yèyinou is a loyal ALIDé client because she has already had five loans, which have all been repaid.  Constantly concerned about enhancing her business, she would like to obtain a sixth loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fresh shrimp

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James K., 62, from Kapkiamo village, is married and the father of eight children: Robert, Kenneth Kiprutto, Kibet, Milka, Kangogo, Jepchumba and Kipkulei.

James operates a retail shop in Kapkiamo and a taxi. He started his business twenty years ago and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 16,000.

He was introduced to KADET by existing clients. This loan will be James’ third from KADET.  He has borrowed Kshs 40,000 to purchase items like soap, sugar, cooking oil, tea leaves and more for his business.  If this loan boosts his business he will use the extra profit to purchase a dairy cow and to educate his children.

He hopes to purchase more new cars for the taxi business and to expand his retail shop into a supermarket.  James describes himself as hardworking and committed.

loans.use: Purchase stock for retail shop.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is a 48-year-old married man living in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale. He has six children, ranging in age from five to 20 years old.  All of them attend school.

Alfred has been running his farm for over twenty years.  He sells a wide variety of products at the local market, like maize, beans and bananas.  He earns extra income as a welder.  

Alfred has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, having recently completed a loan of Kes. 30,000.  He now requests a loan of Kes. 62,400 to purchase and insure a quality dairy cow. He says the animal will require a lot of effort, though he fully appreciates the extra milk production.

He hopes that the profit from the loan will help him further his children's education and meet their need for food. 

Alfred has big plans for expansion in the next five to 10 years.  His main goal is to acquire another six acres of land. He also wants to have 10 good dairy cows and to upgrade his poultry farm to a maximum of 1400 hens.

loans.use: Buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is a 39-year-old lady married to a builder and together they have six children. They both contribute to the family welfare; each one helps out the other in keeping their family of seven afloat.

Margret operates a clothing shop in Hoima, Uganda, and is also a tailor. She has been in the business for seventeen years now and wants her business to grow to bigger heights so that she becomes a big supplier of clothing material. She also farms to complement her business for sustainability.

Margret wishes to buy school uniform clothing materials to sell using the loan funds from HOFOKAM.

loans.use: To buy school uniform clothing materials

loans.name: Padmakumari

texts.en:
Padmakumari is a 25-year-old married woman with two children. Her elder daughter is studying now, while the other one is a still a young child. Her husband is a fisherman.

Padmakumari has a small tailoring and clothes-selling business. One of her specialties is creating small mosquito nets. She started her business two years ago. Her business is a small one, but it is very attractive, and there is a very strong demand for her mosquito nets. She increases her business scale step by step, and is a very honest businesswoman.

Padmakumari is looking for some additional financial support to expand her business, so she has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka.

Her future ambition is to renovate her own house with the increased income from her business.

loans.use: To purchase cloth for her tailoring business

loans.name: Bukky

texts.en:
Bukky hails from Ajibade town in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a trader; she sells groceries and foodstuffs of all kind in her shop. She has been in the business for the past 15 years and she is working hard to pull her family out of poverty. 

Bukky is married with five children. They are still in secondary school. She is 40 years of age and her husband is a businessman. She believes in women supporting their husbands in taking care of the home morally, financially and otherwise.

Bukky hopes for a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for the financial support at this crucial time.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Asma's Group

texts.en:
A. is from the city Borewala, famous for its shrines in Pakistan.  Her husband is an auto-rickshaw driver by profession (three-wheeled motor vehicle).  He earns an income of Pak Rs.300 per day.  He has been in business for over 5 years. 

A. stays at home to look after their children and to tend to household chores.  She is requesting a loan of Pak Rs. 20,000 to repair her husband's rickshaw.

loans.use: Repair an auto-rickshaw.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is a 30-year-old married man with one child. He completed the primary level of education.

The borrower has a bakery that he wants to develop. He has significant experience in this business and has a two employees. He will use this loan to purchase an electric kneading machine and flour for his shop. This will help him to increase his productivity and his income.

loans.use: Purchase a kneading machine

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 44 years old and married to Patrick Mutisya.  She has been selling fruits and vegetables to her clients in small quantities in the town of Naivasha since 2005.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the cash to build a kiosk from where she can operate her green grocery business.

In future, Jane's dream is to have a big grocery shop that will serve many people that stocks a variety of products that will enable her to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: Build a kiosk.

loans.name: Rubina Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Rubina Kosar is from Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is married and the mother of four children.  For years she has sold medicines.  Her clients are clinics and medical shops in the area. 

Her husband is in the wood selling business, but despite his good intentions, he isn't able to meet the demand for wood because of a lack of money.  Rubina is requesting a loan to buy enough woods to expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase woods in bulk.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James M. is a 33 year old man married to Grace Mwihaki.  She is a 23 years old housewife. They live in the town of Kabarnet and have two children.  Hezekiah is five years old and Shalim is age two.

James has run a boutique for seven years. He makes a monthly profit of Kshs 18,000.  He earns an additional income of Kshs 12,000 from other sources. 

He was introduced to KADET by existing clients.  This will be his first loan from a micro finance institution. He wants to borrow Kshs 40,000, which he will use to purchase clothes and nets for resale.

If this loan boosts his business he will use the extra income to open another boutique in Marigat Town, which is next to Kabarnet.

James hopes to purchase a plot of land in future and build residential houses.  He describes himself as hardworking

loans.use: Purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat is from a city named Borewala, famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is 45 years old and married with three grown children, who are married. 

Her husband, M. is a mason. Mussarat requests a loan to buy masonry tools for her husband.  This she says will allow them to live comfortably.

loans.use: Buy masonry tools.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 47 year-old married man living in western Kenya, near the town of Kisii. He has five children, ranging in age from 7 to 17 years old.  All of them currently attend school.

David has been running his farm for over twenty years.  He sells a wide variety of products at the local market including milk, cereals, chickens and eggs.  He also buys and sells cattle on occasion.  David says his main challenge is the lack of sufficient capital to take advantage of business opportunities.  He also noted fluctuating market prices for farm produce as a cause for concern.

David has a successful history with Juhudi Kilimo, previously completing two loans of Kes. 45,000 and Kes. 60,000.  He now requests a loan of Kes. 60,000 to purchase a dairy cow.  He says the extra income from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children, and will allow him to provide proper nutrition for his family. 

David has plans for expansion in the next five to 10 years.  His main goal is to acquire a pickup truck to transport his produce.  He also wants to use it to get cattle to and from the market.

loans.use: Purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr: D. Béatrice est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin et vit à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou. Béatrice est mariée à HOUNKPEVI  et est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Béatrice n’a plus personne à sa charge. Béatrice vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Béatrice est secondée par son mari pour les dépenses de la famille. Ainsi, pour participer aux charges familiales, Béatrice vend des tissus. L’achat de ses tissus s’effectue à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est encore à Dantokpa que Béatrice vend ses articles de façon ambulante et par le système de distribution. Béatrice n’a pas fréquenté l’école mais excerce cette activité depuis bientôt sept années. En tant que cliente fidèle de ALIDé, Béatrice a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Béatrice désire renforcer son activité pour satisfaire les divers besoins de sa clientèle, c’est pour cela qu’elle désire obtenir un troisième crédit chez ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Béatrice was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and lives in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou.  She is married to HOUNKPEVI and is the mother of three children, who have all attended school.  She no longer has anyone to support.  She lives together with her husband and children.  Béatrice backs up her husband regarding family expenses.  So, to take part in covering family expenses, she sells cloth, which is purchased from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, where she also sells items from place to place and by the distribution system.  She did not attend school but has been operating this business for almost seven years.  As a loyal ALIDé client, Béatrice has already had two loans, which have both been repaid. She would like to bolster her business to satisfy the diverse needs of her customers.  This is why she would like to obtain a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Ruqaiya Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Ruqaiya parveen is from Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She is the mother of four children: two boys and two girls.  Besides her youngest son who is just two years old, the other kids are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. 

Her husband's name is M. I. and he is a trained cook.  He sells Punjabi foods such as (Dahi Bhalay and Daal Chawal) in the main market. He began selling these products in 2005. 

Ruqaiya is asking for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) to purchase cooking oil, spices, lentils and rice. This loan will help grow her husband’s food business and keep his customers satisfied.

loans.use: Buy food items to cook and sell.

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Чутов Нурулло проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат, имеет 7 детей. Образование средне- специальное "Бухгалтер". По специональности работает уже 18 лет. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. В этой области более 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Он хочет получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Nurullo C. lives in the region of Yavan. He is 47 years old. He is married and has seven children. He has a specialized secondary education in accounting. He has been working in this field for eighteen years. He also does agriculture. He has a plot of land at home where he grows vegetables. He has been doing this for more than ten years. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer. He wants to collect a good harvest for resale.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is 49 years old and married with seven children.  They range in age from one to 22 years old.  Five of them are currently enrolled in school.  He has run a farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, for the past ten years.  His primary source of income comes by selling maize, beans and meat, at the local market to middlemen.  He also operates his own butchery for extra income.  Overall, his main challenges are competition from other meat suppliers and access to good preservation equipment such as fridges. 

Justus requested this loan, his first through Juhudi Kilimo, for Kes. 31,200 to purchase and insure a dairy cow.  He says that the extra income from this loan will improve his family by getting milk for home consumption and selling the surplus. Justus wants to be the main meat and milk supplier in his area.

loans.use: Purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ajose

texts.en:
Ajose sells groceries, foodstuffs, drinks and clothes in her shop located in her house. She has been in her business for the past three years and she is very happy with the nature of her business. 

Ajose's business plan is to buy and sell more goods so she can continue to grow and improve in her business and profitability. She hopes for a very big supermarket in future. She is requesting a loan of 170,000 nairas to purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and drinks in bulk to sell to her numerous customers.

Ajose is married with four children, ages 3, 6, 9 and 12 years old, and they are doing fine. She hopes to assist her husband in sponsoring their education. She thanks Kiva and LAPO for this opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a married woman with two children. She owns a two-room house where she lives with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. She takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals per day. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Catherine owns a stall in Nakawa market selling yellow bananas. She works seven days per week. She would like to purchase more bunches of yellow bananas with the Ush.700,000 loan from MCDT. She rents the space for her business at 20000/= per month. She has been running her business for more than 5 years.  She has at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people.  Her greatest challenges are the rainy season and seasonality. Catherine has worked with MCDT for more than 5 years and chose the organization because they are cooperative. Catherine aspires to go directly to the farmers branch.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of yellow bananas

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley K. is 35 years old and married to Elizabeth Muthoni, who is 25 years old.  They have one child, Adrian K. Kimemu (age four who attends baby Class).

Stanley is a hawker dealing will electronics, cosmetics, utensils, hair-bands and combs.  He's been in this business for the last six years and earns an  average profit of Kshs 10,000. His business is located in Kabarnet town and most of his customers are Kabarnet residence.

Stanley was introduced to Kadet by a friend who wanted to join Kadet at that time, so they both joined.  He wants to borrow Kshs 20,000 to purchase more stock for his business. If this loan boosts his business Stanley intends to rent a house for his business and purchase more stock. 

Stanley would like to specialize in utensils and cosmetics wholesaling.  He also wants to educate his child to the highest level possible and have a fulfilling life.  Stanley describes himself as determined and hardworking.

loans.use: Purchase items to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is a 45-year-old married man with four children. He passed the intermediate level of education.

The entrepreneur sells cosmetics. He is taking this loan to buy cosmetics, perfumes, make-up, and powders, in addition to ladies garments of different types and styles. He has a good reputation in the markets due to his occupation and could gain lots of clients in the market. His family income will rise as a result of this loan.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics, perfumes

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr: A. Colette est née en 1983 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Colette vit depuis 7 ans à Agbodjèdo, un quartier de Cotonou. Mariée à AVAHOU Fulbert, Colette est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Colette est secondée par son mari pour assurer les dépenses familiales. Pour venir en aide à son mari, Colette exerce comme activité la gestion d’une cafétéria. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Colette mène son activité. Colette s’approvisionne également à Dantokpa. Colette exerce son activité depuis bientôt quatre ans bien que n’ayant pas fréquenté l’école. Colette est une cliente fidèle de ALIDé qui a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Colette souhaite développer son activité afin de répondre aux nombreuses attentes de sa clientèle, c’est pour cela qu’elle veut bénéficier d’un troisième concours financiers chez ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Colette was born 1983 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  She has been living in Agbodjèdo, a district of Cotonou, for seven years.  Married to AVAHOU Fulbert, she is the mother of two children who are both in school.  The couple live together with their children.  Colette backs up her husband to ensure that family expenses are covered.  To help out her husband, she runs a cafeteria as her business located at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She also gets her supplies from Dantokpa.  Colette has been in operation for almost four years, even though she did not attend school.  She is a loyal ALIDé client who has already benefited from two loans, which have been repaid.  She wishes to develop her business in order to respond to the numerous expectations of her customers.  This is why she wants to obtain financial assistance from ALIDé for a third time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sugar, concentrated milk, etc.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 27 years old, married and the mother of four children: Titus, Lydia, Kelvin and Dan, ages 10,8, 6 and 4 year.

Gladys operates a salon that she started three years ago, in Kasoiyo. She generates a profit of Kshs, 5,000 per month and has no other source of income. 

Gladys has not borrowed from any other source other than KADET.  She was introduced to KADET by existing clients. She wants to borrow Kshs 20,000 from KADET to purchase stock for her salon, like cosmetics.  If this loan boosts her business Gladys will use the extra profit to educate her children in school.

She has hopes of constructing a big house for her family and also buying a car. Gladys describes herself as active and humble.

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics for her salon business.

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen A. is a forty year old industrious and ambitious lady, married to Joseph O., a supervisor with a passenger transport company.  They have four children ages 20, 18, 16 and 14.

Maureen operates a tailoring business from Yala, a suburb of Kisumu city. She designs clothes for children, ladies and gents.  Apart from this, she also mends torn clothes. Her expertise can be seen in the quality clothes she designs and by the number of clients who come to her stall for tailoring services.

Maureen learned about Kadet Ltd. through a friend who is an existing client. This is her third loan from Kadet Ltd., and she hopes to use the money to increase her stock of materials and purchase another sewing machine since she anticipates more growth.

She aspires to open a wholesale shop where she will be able to stock and supply all kinds of textile material.  Maureen also has a dream of one day opening a tailoring school where she can pass her skills to others to enhance the economic growth of the community.

loans.use: Buy a sewing machine and a stock of textile materials.

loans.name: Nikanou Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Nikanou (cinq femmes mariées dont deux dans des familles polygames) ont en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et résident toutes dans le quartier Bagadadji de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et font l’achat et la vente d’articles divers (céréales, habillements, du lait frais et parures). 
Tata C., un des membres du groupe excelle plutôt dans l’habillement avec l’achat et la vente de pagnes wax, des draps de lit, des couvre lit etc.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de diversifier les articles à vendre, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 2ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursé le premier. 
Tata C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 7 pièces de pagnes wax et une douzaine de draps brodés auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Ségou. Tata effectue sa vente en ambulant dans les quartiers, à domicile et au grand marché de Ségou, à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes qui achètent au comptant et parfois à crédit. 
Tata C. à l’instar des autres membres du groupe espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 14.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et prendre en charge les petits besoins de la famille en condiments. 
Elles ont pour ambitions d’acheter  chacune un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The women of the group Nikanou (five married including two in polygamous families) average 40 years of age and five children each.  They all reside in the Bagadadji district in Ségou City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women of the group know one another through community ties, and they buy and sell various goods (grains, clothing, fresh milk, and fine accessories).  Tata C., one of the members of the group, rather excels in clothing with her commerce in wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), bed sheets, blanket, etc.  With the goal of increasing their working capital and diversifying the items for sale, the members of the group decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan after having repaid the first one.  Tata C. intends to use her loan for buying seven bolts of wax pagnes and a dozen embroidered bed sheets from wholesalers at the big market of Ségou.  Tata sells door-to-door in the area, out of her home, and at the big market of Ségou.  Her customers are generally composed of men and women who buy with cash and sometime on credit. Like the other members of the group, Tata C. hopes to make an average monthly profit of 14,500 francs that will be used for repaying the loan and for meeting the sundry needs of the family in terms of condiments.  They each have the ambition to buy a residential plot of land. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth and embroidered bed sheets

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is a fresh unmarried boy of 20 who completed the primary level of education. He has a barber shop and he is taking this loan is to create new decorations for the shop and to purchase barbering items, such as machine clips, hair dryers, and all the other necessities of the shop. Although he is very young, he has a good reputation in the markets and his youth attracts a lot of clients, because he is sensitive to their needs and tastes. He knows all the modern styles of hair cutting. With this loan, he was able to raise his standard of living and is more ambitious. Looking forward to a brighter future, he intends to hire more employees to serve his increasing number of clients.

loans.use: Shop decorations, tools, and supplies

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 28 year old single man who lives with his five year old child.  He runs a tailoring shop where he makes clothes to earn a living.  He was previously operating a barber shop before he ventured into this business. 

Stephen says that the main challenge he faces in business is high customer demand and he has difficulty keeping up with orders.  He hopes to buy more sewing machines to expand his business.  He has requested a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a sewing machine, fabric and sewing threads.

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine, thread and fabric.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah is a single mother. She owns a two-room house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. She takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals per day. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Hadjah owns a stall in Ndeeba market selling bananas. She works seven days per week. She would like to purchase more bunches of bananas with the Ush. 800,000 loan from MCDT. She rents the space for her business at 15000/= per month. She has been running the business for many years.  She has at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both at retail and at wholesale.  Her greatest challenges are the rainy season and seasonality, because she works from an open place. Hadjah has worked with MCDT for a long time and chose the organization because it was easy to join. Hadjah aspires to go directly to farmers to buy bananas.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 40 years old, married and lives with his wife and their child, who is five years old.  He has been selling clinic equipments since 2008.  He was previously employed in a pharmacy before he started this business.   

His wife is a business lady and together they share their family expenses.  Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, his business has grown because he can access loans.  He hopes to increase his income in the future.  He has requested a loan of kes 20,000 to add a stock of gloves and medicine. He describes himself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: Buy clinical gloves and medicine.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This entrepreneur is a 46-year-old married man with three children. He has passed the intermediate level of education. He has a shop for repairing automobiles. He is using this loan to buy a generator for his shop. He has a good reputation in the market and is able to obtain a lot of clients. He has acquired a great deal of experiences in the scope of his occupation. His family income has been increased due to this shop. He is trustworthy borrower.

loans.use: To buy a generator for his auto repair shop

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is into rental services; she rents out canopies, plastic chairs and tables to make ends meet. She is very happy with her business and she is well known in her locality. She has so many customers as a result of her popularity. With the proceeds from the business, she assists and supports her husband in financing the home. 

Roseline is married with six children and her husband is doing well in his business too. She is 60 years of age and, even at her age, she is still business-conscious. She hopes for a loan of 170,000 nairas to purchase more canopies, plastic chairs and tables to meet the demand of her numerous customers in town. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more canopies, plastic chairs and tables

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de dix femmes mariées dont Dangourou D. ayant 33 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans une famille polygame dans le village de Kamakono dans la commune urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Les membres de groupe Benkadi se sont connus à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et d’embrasser d’autres activités génératrices de revenus, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme de Soro Yiriwaso, notamment Dangourou D., la présidente du groupe. 
Dangourou est à leur 2ème  prêt, après avoir bien remboursé le premier et compte utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 30 sacs de mil et 20 sacs de riz. 
Elle s’approvisionne en céréales sur place auprès des producteurs du village et à la foire hebdomadaire de Beni et effectue sa vente au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle mixte à domicile et dans les villages environnants. 
Elles comptent réaliser  chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge les soins de santé des enfants et réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dangourou a pour ambition de diversifier  son activité avec l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of ten married women, including Dangourou D. who is 33 years old, has three children and lives in a polygamous household in the village of Kamakono in the Ségou region (the fourth largest administrative region of Mali). The members of the Benkadi group met through marital, neighbourly and parenting links. Looking to increase their business funds and diversify into other revenue-generating business activities, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso programme; this was mostly thanks to Dangourou D., the group's president. Benkadi are on their second loan, having successfully repaid their first, and envisage using the second to buy 30 bags of millet and 20 bags of rice. They source cereals from local suppliers and at the weekly market at Beni; they sell these goods for cash and on credit to a mixed customer base at home and in the surrounding villages. They intend to generate an average monthly profit of 28,000 FCFA each which would be used towards their children's healthcare and for reinvesting in the business. Dangourou's aim is to diversify her business by raising small ruminant animals.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cereal

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is a 24-year-old married man who has completed the primary level of eduction. He has a workshop for repairing automobiles and wanted a loan to buy spare parts for cars.

He has borrowed this money to develop his shop in the industrial zone where there are many workshops. He will be able to expand his shop because of this loan. He has a good reputation in the market. He has acquired a great deal of experience in his work field. His income has also been raised and he is hoping to get more clients, benefit from his experience, and expand his shop more in the future.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for cars

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Djekafo est un regroupe de 10 femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 31 ans, 5 enfants et habitant toutes le village de Kamakono dans la commune urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté.
Djekafo fait le commerce d’articles divers et Fatoumata Traoré qui  est des membres excelle dans les activités d’achat et de vente de mil, d’arachide, de maïs et de riz.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, ce groupe est son 2ème  prêt solidaire et Fatoumata Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 25 sacs de mil et 15 sacs de riz. 
Elle s’approvisionne en céréales sur place à Kamakono avec les producteurs du village et à la foire hebdomadaire de Beni.
Deux d’entre elles vendent parfois du bois de chauffe cueilli par elles mêmes en brousse. 
Les marchandises sont revendues en espèce, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes à domicile et dans les villages environnants.
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour assurer les soins de santé et réinvesti dans l’activité.
 Elles ont pour ambitions  de diversifier les activités en élevant les petits ruminants qui seront revendus en cas de besoins ou utilisés dans des cas sociaux (mariage ou baptême).
texts.en:
Djekafo is a group of ten married women who mostly live in polygamous households and are 31 years old with 5 children; they all live in the village of Kamakono in Ségou region (the fourth largest administrative region in Mali). They met through marital, neighbourly and parental ties. Djekafo sell various products, and Fatoumata Traoré, who is one of its members, excels in the purchase and sale of millet, peanuts, corn and rice. Having already successfully repaid their first loan, the group are on their second, and Fatoumata Traoré aims to use it to buy 25 bags of millet and 15 bags of rice. They purchase their cereals from local suppliers in Kamakono and at the Beni weekly market, and two of them also sometimes sell firewood that they have collected themselves. The goods are sold for cash through retail sales and on credit to a mixed customer base, both through home sales and in the neighbouring villages. They envisage generating an average monthly profit of 25,000FCFA which would be used to see to their family's healthcare and to reinvest into the business. Their aim is to diversify their business activities through raising small ruminant animals which would be re-sold if necessary, or used for social occasions (weddings or baptisms).

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing cereals

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 31 years old and married with one child who goes to school. She rears animals to earn a living. She is also employed as a civil servant and therefore earns a monthly salary.  She uses her income to support her family and to educate her child. 

She hopes to open a cosmetics shop and improve her living conditions in the future. Being a member of Faulu Kenya, she has been trained on how to manage her business. This has made her business to grow to a higher level.  

She has requested for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Kiva partner Faulu Kenya to buy animal feeds.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds

loans.name: Ajoke

texts.en: Ajoke thanks all who made her last Kiva loan possible, as having extra capital in the business gave her business a new outlook. She is a trader; she sells frozen food like turkey parts, chicken parts and foodstuffs in her shop. Ajoke has been in her business for the past 15 years and she is happy with the nature of her business. Ajoke hopes for more expansion in her business. She wants to buy one deep freezer so she can open another shop where can sell and make more profit for her business and family upkeep. She hopes for a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase a deep freezer to preserve her foodstuffs, frozen food like chicken, turkey and ice fish to sell. Ajoke, 45 years old, is married with four children. She says thanks to lenders for the financial empowerment.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is married with four children who attend school. She rents a three-room house where she lives with eight people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. She takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals per day. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees. 

Eva owns a retail shop market selling all kinds of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap and other items. She works seven days per week. She would like to purchase more bags of sugar, cartons of salt and boxes of soap with the Ush. 800,000 loan from MCDT. She rents the space for her business at 45000/= per month. She has been running her business for ten years.  She has at least 30 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail.  Her greatest challenges are the rainy season and seasonality because she works from a muddy place. Eva has worked with MCDT for seven years and chose the organization because of their good services. Eva hopes to sell only at wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Kalyanawathi

texts.en:
Kalyanawathi is a 53-year-old married woman living with her husband and two daughters. One daughter is an undergraduate at one of the universities in Sri Lanka. Kalyanawathi is an educated woman. Her husband has a wood carving business which Kalyanawathi supports. They started the business six years ago. The business started very small but now it has grown considerably. Kalyanawathi has a lot of experience in this field. She is a hardworking woman and very happy about her present family situation.  She handles the responsibility of managing a family very well.  

Additionally, Kalyanawathi is the secretary of this Village Organization – a group of about 40 women who form a village group within the BRAC organization. Kalyanawathi is seeking a 25,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC to help expand the wood carving business. Ultimately she hopes to use her additional income to help pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: For a wood carving business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 37-year-old married lady who is blessed with three children. She sells milk and also runs a grocery shop. She has been in this business for 10 years and she has become more focused after training by Faulu Kenya Ltd., a Kiva partner.  

She hopes to be a major supplier of milk and vegetables in her area. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milking to increase her output.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Siguitèmasson Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Siguitèmasson sont mariés majoritairement dans des  grandes familles polygames  avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Darabougou dans la Commune Rurale de Sakoïba (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles et se sont connues à travers des liens de  parenté, de mariage, voisinage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes du village de Darabougou. 
Ce  groupe qui excelle dans l’achat et la vente des produits alimentaires a,  en son sein Assan D. qui s’est spécialisée dans le commerce de condiments alimentaires  tels  les oignons et les choux.
C’est dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle que ce groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec  qui il est à son premier prêt solidaire.
Assan D. envisage utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs d’oignons frais et 4 sacs de choux pommés auprès des producteurs qui alimentent la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. La vente de ses articles se fait au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes à domicile, en ambulant à travers le village et à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.670FCA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer à l’achat  de nourriture, à l’augmentation de fonds de commerce et à la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles).
texts.en:
The six members of the Siguitèmasson group are married and generally live in large polygamous families; they are on average 36 years old and have four children. They all live in the village of Darabougou in the rural municipality of Sakoïba (the fourth largest administrative region of Mali). They met through parental, marital and neighbourly ties, and through their membership of a traditional association for women in Darabougou. Assan D. works for this group, which excels in the purchase and sale of food products; his speciality is the sale of condiments such as onions and cabbage. The group is concerned about addressing its customers' needs, and so it has decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit association with whom it is on its first loan. Assan D. envisages using this loan to buy 5 bags of fresh onions and 4 bags of cabbage from producers who supply the weekly fair in Ségou. These products are sold through retail sales and on credit to a mixed customer base at home, through mobile sales in the village and at the weekly Ségou fair. They aim to generate an average monthly wage of 15,560FCFA which would be used to purchase food, to increase the business funds and for social events (weddings, baptisms and funerals).

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Isaack Njoroge

texts.en:
Isaack C. is a gentleman who is 31 years old and married to Ann Njoroge, who is 29 years old and a housewife. They have two children: Naomi (5 years old) and Daniel (2 years old). Isaack runs a mobile hawking business moving from market to market selling his commodities which include watches, hair accessories and others. Most of his clients are women. He started this business six years ago.


Isaack was introduced to KADET by an existing client and he does not have a previous credit history. He has borrowed 20,000 Kenyan shillings which he will use to purchase commodities that are in very high demand in the market right now. These include pots "sufurias", cups, trays, etc. He plans to use the extra profit to expand his mobile business. 


Isaack hopes to expand his business so that it becomes a one stop business shop and not a mobile business. He wants to repay all the borrowed money and ask for a bigger loan. He describes himself as a person whose future is in business.

loans.use: To buy some more goods for his hawking business with items like pots, cups, trays and others

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria has been a widow for some years now and she has five children. They are three boys and two girls; she cares for them alone. She sells groceries and foodstuffs in her shop and she has been in the business for the past six years. She is very happy with the growth of her business and she hopes for the loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all lenders for their wonderful support.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan K. is a 23-year-old lady. She operates a boutique together with her business partner, Jennifer Tallam. They started this business four years ago and make a profit of 8,000 Kenyan shillings. Their business is situated in Kabarnet market and their main customers are residents of the area. Joan hopes to open many wholesale clothes outlets and describes herself as hardworking.

This is Joan's first time obtaining funding from a financial institution. She was introduced by existing clients. She has borrowed 40,000 Kenyan shillings which she intends to use to purchase jackets, T-shirts and other new clothes. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to extend her business to other trading centers.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes stock

loans.name: David Ng'a'nga

texts.en:
David N. is a man of forty-eight years who is married and the father to eight lovely children. He lives in Soy in Eldoret, where he grows maize. David has been farming for twenty-four years now and he also does dairy farming where he sells milk mostly to his neighbors and other dairy industries along Likuyani in Eldoret.

David was introduced to KADET by KADET clients. He has applied for a loan which he plans to use to buy farm inputs like fertilizer, top-dressing to help the maize grow faster, herbicides, and also to pay his employees.

David’s goal is to become a better farmer, to teach others good farming, and also to provide the basic needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy farm imputs like fertilizer, top dressing and herbicides and to pay his employees

loans.name: Clarah Jeptanui

texts.en:
Clarah K. is a woman of 38. She is married and has four children, who are all in primary school. She lives in Kipsangui in Eldoret, where she plants maize and wheat for resale on her 2 acres of land. Most of her clients are her neighbors. Clarah has been farming for three years now.

Clarah came to know about KADET, a Kiva partner, through another existing client and this will be her third loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy fertilizers and pay her employees. 

Her goal is to add 3 acres of land in the near future so that she can increase the family's income and hence, increase their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs like fertilizer, maize seedlings

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en:
Jeremiah is a 30-year-old, married man living in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale. He has three children, ranging in age from 2 to 7 years old. The eldest two attend school.

Jeremiah has been running his mixed farm for over four years now. He sells a wide variety of products at the local market. His primary income comes from the sale of maize, potatoes and bananas. He also runs a small kiosk and molds bricks for extra income. He says that lately, the main challenge he faces is the availability and cost of animal feed as his plot of land is too small for grazing.

Jeremiah is taking his first loan with Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 31,200 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him pay his children's school fees and take care of all their basic needs. He also wants to improve their home and their overall health.

Jeremiah has plans for expansion in the next 5-10 years and his main goal is to acquire four good dairy animals. He also wants to have a poultry farm so that he can supply chicks to other farmers in the area.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is widowed with six children. All of her children have finished school. She owns a four-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Imelda takes care of grandchildren who go to school.  The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Imelda owns a restaurant in Kitawuluzi where she serves all types of food ranging from traditional to snacks like chips and soft drinks. She works seven days a week. Imelda receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Besides this restaurant business, she also sells second hand clothes in a nearby shop and has a stall of food and vegetables.

 Imelda has been in this business for 30 years prior to this business she was a and her business challenges include seasonality. Imelda has been with MCDT for eight years, servicing her 26th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock of food for the restaurant, to buy crates of soda and boxes of Safi, mineral water and splash,  and to buy second hand clothes.  She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start a fully refurnished hotel.

She was supposed to get the loan on 18/03/10 but got it on 19/03/10 because of pre-Agm (pre- Annual General meeting)

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs, drinks and  other items.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
Sally J. is a twenty nine old woman who is married to Nicholas Kemei. They are blessed with four lovely children who are all in primary school. She lives in Kipsangui in Eldoret where she practices farming, specializing in maize and wheat. She harvests the produce which she sells to her neighbors. She also practices dairy farming and sells milk as well.  She has been farming for three years now. 

Sally was introduced to KADET by another existing client and this will be her third loan. She plans to use the loan to buy items for her farm such as fertilizers and maize seedlings. 

Her goal is to become a better farmer and increase the family income so that they can have better lives.

loans.use: To buy items for her farm such as fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Asca Bekyibei

texts.en:
Asca T., 56, is married and the mother of seven lovely children. She lives in Kipsangui, Eldoret area. She owns a ten acre plot where she plants maize for resale. Most of her customers are her neighbors. She has been in the farming business for three years now, however, she also sells milk and passion fruits. 

Asca was introduced to KADET by an existing client. She has applied for a loan which she will use to buy fertilizers and maize seedlings. 

Asca's immediate goal is to buy another ten acre plot of land to increase her production and, therefore, get more income with which to feed her family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and maize seedlings.

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade sells foodstuffs and groceries. Her shop is in front of her house. She has been in the business for the past five years. She manages the business with her children in Lagos. Her business plan is to have another shop in a busier area so that she can increase her productivity and profitability. She hopes for a loan of 170,000 nairas to buy more foodstuffs and groceries to sell. 

Folashade is married with four children who are in primary and secondary schools. She is 40 years old and her husband is a mechanical engineer. He also works hard to provide for the home financially. She expresses her huge gratitude to Kiva for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries, foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Amy

texts.en: Amy F. is 46 years old and a widowed mother of two. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" THIECKENE for six years and has always paid back her loans on time. Her main activity consists of selling fruits at the local market. With this loan, Amy F. will buy more fruits which she will resell.

loans.use: To buy fruits for resale

loans.name: Johanna

texts.es:
Yojanna N. varón tiene 34 años y vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos en las edades de 5 a 16 años, que estudian  en los niveles universitario, bachiller y transición, su negocio está localizado en la capita de Colombia, específicamente en el barrio minuto de Dios, el cual está rodeado de Centros comerciales, parques recreativos y ciclo rutas.     Johanna  solicita un crédito que invertirá en la  compra de  maquinarias de confección que adicionará a  su negocio llamado  Gavatex, constituido como una empresa unipersonal, donde presta el servicio de diseño, corte y confección de prendas de vestir desde hace 5 años. Este es su segundo crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo  y se siente contenta porque de tres máquinas que tiene en su negocio, pasa a 5 con este nuevo crédito.
Su sueño es continuar acompañando a sus hijos en su crecimiento personal y desarrollar su profesión y su misión como mujer; así como su gran desafío es también salirle al frente a la competencia que generan muchos productos chinos, que aunque no superan la calidad de los suyos,  la inquietan, por eso constantemente debe estar atenta a su mercado para fortalecer sus clientes rentables y no tener dificultades en la comercialización de sus productos; otro de sus  grandes desafíos es la  recuperación de su cartera en empresas grandes que constantemente deben ser controlada generando menos financiación para ellos.
texts.en:
Yojanna, 34, lives with her husband and three children, whose ages range from 5 to 16 years. The children are all students: university, high-school and pre-school. Her business in located in Colombia’s capital, specifically in the Minuto de Dios neighborhood, which is surrounded by shopping centers, recreational parks and bike lanes Johanna is asking for funds to buy sewing machines to add to her business, called Gavatex, which is classified as a single-owner business. She has designed and manufactured clothing for the last 5 years. This is her second loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she is happy because this loan will make it possible for her to grow from three sewing machines to five. Her dream is to continue to guide her children through their personal growth and to develop her profession and mission as a woman. A major challenge for her is to succeed despite the competition represented by the large influx of Chinese products. Despite their being of inferior quality to those she produces, she is uneasy nonetheless. For this reason, she must be constantly vigilant of the market in order to strengthen her profitable customers and not have any difficulty in marketing her products. Another great challenge is recuperating her large commercial customers which are constantly being controlled and having their budgets reduced.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sewing machines.

loans.name: Ilva

texts.es:
