Ilva M. D. G., tiene 62 años y vive con su esposo, (a su lado en la fotografia)en el barrio José Antonio Galán D. Barranquilla, se dedica al comercio D. mercancías variadas especialmente D. calzado y justamente esta solicitando un crédito por valor D. $2.300.000 para comprar  este articulo en mayor cantidad , vestuario y juegos D. cubre lechos para cumplir pedidos D. sus clientes.

Tiene 8 hijos desD. 28 a 42 años y todos están trabajando, inició su negocio desD. hace 25 años con el apoyo D. su esposo para cubrir los gastos del hogar y contribuir al sostenimiento D. su casa. DesD. el año 2006 está recibiendo créditos con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con  los 4 a los que ha aplicado, logró ensanchar y expandir su negocio. Sueña con tener una gran miscelánea donD. sus clientes encuentren todo cuanto necesiten; Su máximo desafío son los que trae consigo la edad, el  día a día vivir y levantarse saludable y con ganas D. trabajar. El barrio donD. habita es un sector popular donD. encuentra apoyo en sus  vecinos y se realizan muchas actividades culturales  propias D. la Región Caribe.
texts.en:
Ilva M. D. G. is 62 years old and lives with her husband (also in the photo) in the José Antonio Galán neighborhood of Barranquilla. She sells several types of merchandise, especially footwear, and she is asking for this loan of 2,300 Colombian pesos so she can buy greater quantities of shoes, clothing and bed covers to fill orders from her customers. Ilva has eight children between 28 and 42 years old, and all of them are working. With her husband's support, she started her business 25 years ago to cover household expenses and contribute to the upkeep of the house. Since 2006 she has been taking out loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With the four loans she has received, she managed to expand her business. Ilva dreams of having a large variety of merchandise so her customers can find whatever they need. Her biggest challenges are those which come with age -- living from day to day and staying healthy and ready to work. The neighborhood she lives in is a popular area where neighbors help each other and where there are many cultural activities typical of the Caribbean region.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bulk purchases of shoes, clothing and bed covers to fill customer orders

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is widowed with two children and both of her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Florence doesn’t take care of any additional family, but she does pay for rent, school fees and feeding her immediate family. 

Florence owns a stall selling charcoal in Mengo-Kisenyi.  Besides this charcoal business, she also sells foodstuffs at her stall  She works seven days a week. Florence receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Her business challenges including transport costs.  

Florence wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more sacks of charcoal and foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, cassava and sweet potatoes. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to get money to construct her own house. She joined MCDT because she could access loans easily after a group consensus.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and bananas

loans.name: Edwin

texts.es:
El Señor Edwin Solís C. tiene 25 años, está casado con la Señora Miguelina Marquina tiene  27 años, tienen una hija de 4 años, ellos viven en la comunidad de palca grande a 90 km de la ciudad de Sacaba, son personas humildes de escasos recursos , no tienen capital para ampliar el negocio de venta de abarrotes, en la tienda tienen los productos de primera necesidad; arroz, azúcar, fideo, aceite, sal y gas  licuado, por otro se dedican a la producción de tubérculos (papa), la comunidad se encuentra muy alejado de la ciudad, el transporte a la zona es muy escaso los camiones solo salen una vez a la semana.

El Edwin no tiene capital para agrandar la tienda de abarrotes, por lo  tanto necesita un capital  para agrandar la tienda, en la zona es la única tiendo donde provee estos productos de primera necesidad, por lo tanto para ellos es muy difícil acudir en busca de préstamo a los bancos a la ciudad, CIDRE se encuentra más cerca y trabaja con la comunidad rurales se encuentra cerca donde ellos pueden acudir a un préstamo para mejorar el negocio que tienen.

La esposa de Edwin, doña Miguelina nos comenta que su mayor sueño es sacar a su hija una enfermera en salud y para que su hija estudie y salga profesional quiere tener suficiente capacidad económica y tener ahorros en un banco para hacer estudiar y luego trabajaría  en la misma comunidad según ella machas mujeres  sufren de  mucho enfermedades  así su hija puede ayudar a la gente humilde de la comunidad.
texts.en:
Edwin Solís C., 25, is married to Miguelina Marquina, 27, and they have a 4-year-old daughter. They live in Palca Grande, 90 kilometers from the city of Sacaba. They are humble, low-income people that lack funds to enlarge their grocery store. They sell basic needs items: rice, sugar, pasta, cooking oil, salt and liquefied gas. Additionally, they farm tubers (potatoes). The community is quite removed from the city; public transportation in the area is sporadic, buses are available once a week only. Edwin lacks funds to increase his grocery inventory so he needs funding to do so. His store is the only one in the area that provides these basic need items. It is very difficult for them to go to traditional banks in the city to solicit loans. CIDRE is closer and works with rural communities so they are able to call upon it to request loans to improve their business. Edwin’s wife, Miguelina, tells us that her greatest dream is that her daughter become a nurse. In order for this to happen, she must have funds enough and savings to pay for her studies. Her hope is that she would later come back to work in the community because many women suffer illnesses and her daughter could then help the humble people of her community.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 29 years old, married and has three children. She has devoted her life to farming which she works at with her husband.  She sells milk to her neighbors and to local residents. Margaret is a hardworking lady who strives to provide for her family and to educate her children.  She appreciates Faulu Kenya for the training they have offered her. She has become optimistic and focused in her business. She hopes to buy a piece of land and to improve her living standards in the future. She has requested for a loan of kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy chicken manure, fertilizer, dairy feed and an upgraded calf.

loans.use: To buy chicken manure, fertilizer, dairy meal and an upgraded calf

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 39 years old and has been farming for ten years in the Kitale region of Western Kenya. She cultivates a mixed crop and sells maize, bananas, potatoes, and vegetables at the local market. She also earns some extra income selling second-hand clothing. She says the greatest challenge to her business remains the changing weather patterns, which have been a big setback because it makes it difficult to plan farming operations appropriately. 

She requested this loan for Ksh. 31,200 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow to add to her farm. She says that because this is her first loan she will work hard to achieve greater things as far as her farming is concerned. Joan says that she feels optimistic that through Juhudi she will liase with other members to pool together their resources to buy and operate a mini-chilling plant for their milk in the next five years. 

Joan is married with seven children, five of whom are attending school. She hopes that the added income generated by this loan will be a boost for her family by allowing her children to get a quality education and have a quality meal at the end of the day.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
La historia de Juan Carlos M. Pinillo, un hombre de 41 años de edad del barrio Modelo de Barranquilla, es de un éxito impresionante, ya que ha logrado muchas metas en los dos años cortos que está vinculado a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Cuando ingresó en a finales del año 2007 pasó de ser comerciante independiente a iniciar un negocio de llamadas. A pesar de haber empezado con un celular prestado y de no haber tenido tanto éxito vendiendo minutos cerca de una universidad, siguió intentándolo en otras partes y se estableció en su casa. Usó sus dos créditos anteriores para comprar los computadores que hoy en día forman parte principal de su café Internet. Al lado del servicio de Internet con sus cuatro computadores, sigue vendiendo minutos con sus cuatro líneas telefónicas y también se dedica a la venta de refrescos, dulcería y pasabolas. El crédito que actualmente solicita es de $2.300.000 que invertirá en la adquisición de una fotocopiadora y la compra de otro computador, que le permitirán prestar un mejor servicio.
En los dos años que tiene su negocio, siente que ha crecido mucho en muy corto tiempo, que las posibilidades de capacitaciones le han ayudado mucho y que se ha organizado en su negocio y  aporta más dinero a su familia. A pesar de su éxito, considera algunas veces que no posee todos los recursos disponibles para tener más equipos y ampliar el negocio como lo desea, ya que sus clientes tienen mayores exigencias. Además de enfrentar este desafío, su meta es de ampliar y llegar a vender todo relacionado con papelería; y sueña con comprar una casa propia, ya que actualmente vive con su familia en casa de un tío.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos M. Pinillo’s success story is impressive. The 41-year-old man lives in Barranquilla’s Modelo neighborhood. He has reached several goals in the two short years he has been associated with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. When he joined in 2007 he went from being an independent merchant to establishing his phone call service. Despite starting out with a borrowed cell phone and not being very successful at selling service minutes near the university, he kept trying in other parts of town and he set himself up for business in his home. He used his two prior loans to buy computers that today make up the core of his Internet café business. In addition to his four computer Internet service, he has four phone lines available and also sells soft-drinks, candy and snacks. He is currently asking for a $2.300.000 loan to buy a photocopying machine and another computer which will allow him to provide better service. He feels that he has grown a lot in the two years that he’s had his business; that the training opportunities have helped him quite a bit and he has become better organized in his business thus producing higher income for his family. Despite his success, however, he sometimes feels that he doesn’t have the necessary resources to have more equipment and enlarge his business as he’d like to in order to meet increased customer demand. In addition to facing this challenge, his goal is to enlarge his business to have everything related to stationery. He also dreams with owning his own house because he and his family currently live in an uncle’s house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a photocopying machine and a computer.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a 26 year old married man.  His wife runs a salon.  He offers computer services such as printing documents and making business cards. He also sells rubber stamps in his shop to earn a living. He has been involved in this business for one and a half years and has one employee.  He hopes to open outlets and improve his living standards in the future.  He has requested for a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy a computer.

loans.use: To purchase a computer

loans.name: Justus

texts.en: Justus is a 29 year old single man. He runs a general merchandise shop where he sells sugar, soaps, cooking fat and maize flour to earn a living. He has been in this business for four years and has one employee. He also practices farming and plumbing to improve his living conditions. He hopes to expand his business and improve his living standards in the future.  He has requested for a loan of kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to stock more maize flour, sugar, salt and cooking fat.

loans.use: To add stock of sugar, maize flour and salt

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: N. Elisabeth est née à Akppo-Misserete à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Elisabeth vit depuis 6 ans à Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à ADANMETONDE Gislain, un soudeur, Elisabeth est mère de deux enfants dont un seul est scolarisé. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Elisabeth se joint à son mari pour partager les charges de la famille. Pour participer aux dépenses familiales, Elisabeth exerce comme activité la vente de divers condiments (tomâtes, cubes, oignons, piments etc.) et de légumes non loin de son domicile. Elisabeth s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cela fait maintenant cinq ans que Elisabeth fait son commerce mais elle n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. En tant que cliente fidèle de ALIDé, Elisabeth a déjà obtenu deux prêts qui ont été bien remboursés. Elisabeth sollicite un troisième prêt pour renforcer son activité car ses moyens financiers sont limités.
texts.en:
Elisabeth N. was born in Akppo-Misserete in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Elisabeth has lived for six years in Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. Married to Gislain Adanmetonde, a welder, Elisabeth is the mother of two children, only one of whom goes to school. The couple lives together with their children. Elisabeth and her husband share family responsibilities. To help pay the family's expenses, Elisabeth sells various condiments (tomatoes, onions, seasoning, hot peppers, etc.) and vegetables not far from her home. She stocks up on supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Elisabeth has now done this work for five years. She never went to school. As a faithful client of ALIDé, Elisabeth has already received two loans which she repaid in full. She is asking for a third loan to strengthen her business because her financial means are limited.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various condiments (tomatoes, onions, seasoning, hot peppers, etc.) and vegetables

loans.name: Padmini

texts.en:
Padmini is a 49-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband and three sons, one of whom is married and the others are still in school. Her husband has a job in the government.

Padmini has a business making items out of coir, which involves taking the fibers from coconut shells and weaving them into household goods such as string, rope, or floor mats. Her children help her in the business, but she runs it independently otherwise. She has run this business for ten years now, and wants to expand it further.

Padmini is asking for a 50,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to purchase more coir.

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy more coir

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade is 35 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a building contractor and they live in Lagos state, Nigeria. With the proceeds from her store selling frozen food, Folashade has been able to be a good mother and wife in her home. She has had the business for seven years and hopes to expand. Folashade is requesting a loan of NGN 150, 000 to buy more frozen chicken, turkey and fish to sell and maximize her profit. She thanks all lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen food to sell.

loans.name: Kwamboka

texts.en: Kwamboka is a 28 year old married lady who has two children in school.  For the last five years, she has been running a salon, and before that she sold second-hand clothes. She uses her income to pay wages to her two employees and save some with Faulu Kenya. She hopes to open more salons in the future and employ more people. She has requested for a loan of Kes. 60,000 to buy hair products such as shampoos, hair oil and weaves.  She sees herself having rental houses in the future.

loans.use: To buy hair oil, shampoo and weaves

loans.name: Fatu

texts.en: Fatu H. is 48 years old, divorced and has 5 children: 2 boys and 3 girls. The first is in college, three are in secondary school, and the last one is in nursury school. She sells drinks and gara in Wilberforce and lives where she sell her goods. Since joining LAPO, SL, Fatu has taken three previous loans which she used to improve her business, and used the profit to take care of her family. She is asking for a loan of 2,000,000 Leones to buy more goods for sale, which will allow her to make more improvements in her life.

loans.use: To buy drinks and gara

loans.name: Rosse Mary

texts.es:
La señora Rosse Mary tiene 54 años de edad ella nació en la ciudad de La Paz un departamento de Bolivia ella se vino a Cochabamba, vive un la urbanización Villa Esmeralda.
Ella se vino de la ciudad de La Paz por su niña que sufre de ataques epilépticos y el clima de esa ciudad no le ayuda en su recuperación, tiene tres hijos uno que ya va a la universidad y los otros van al colegio aun ella vive sola porque su esposo se quedo en la ciudad de La Paz al tener un trabajo halla ya que si lo deja no podrá ayudar con la educación a sus hijos.
La señora Rosse Mary tiene una tienda en el barrio donde ella vive Rosse Mary tuvo que dejar su trabajo y no puede aun encontrar un trabajo acá en la ciudad de Cochabamba ella es secretaria y como la situación económica del país es difícil y por la edad que tiene ella está segura de no encontrar trabajo y para tener un ingreso y poder ayudar en la casa y no solo depender del esposo ella decidió abrir la tienda aun que los ingresos no sea altos.
Ella requiere el préstamo para poder aumentar la mercadería de su tienda y tener más variedad de productos de esa manera tendrá más compradores al ver una tienda de barrio que sea completa y de esa manera estará con sus hija y siempre poderla ayudar ella tiene miedo que su hija sufra y que ella no pueda contar con la ayuda de su madre, porque en el colegio saben el problema que tiene Ana.
La señora Rosse Mary es una persona responsable trabajadora y dedicada a sus hijos ella sueña con que sus tres hijos terminen la universidad y poder hacer una carrera aunque técnica como la de ella para que tengan un futuro mejor y ella les da todo lo que está a su alcance tanto económicamente como espiritualmente les enseña a ser personas de bien.
texts.en:
Rosse Mary is 54 years old and was born in the city of La Paz in Bolivia before she came to Cochabamba where she lives in the Villa Esmeralda development.

She left the city of La Paz for her daughter who suffers from epileptic attacks; the climate of La Paz was not helping her recovery. She has three children, one who has already left for university and the others who go to high school although she lives alone because her husband stayed in La Paz to work since if he left he would not be able to help with the education of their children.

Mrs. Rosse Mary has a store in the neighborhood where she lives. Rosse Mary had left her job in La Paz and couldn't find work here in the city of Cochabamaba. She had been a secretary but because of the poor economic state of the country and her age she was sure she would be unable to find work. In order to have an income and be able to help out with the household without depending entirely on her husband she decided to open a store even though the profits are not large.

She needs a loan in order to increase the store's merchandise and increase the variety of products she sells in order to have more customers when they see that the store is complete. If this happens she will be able to stay with her daughter and always be able to help her because she is afraid that her daughter is suffering and cannot count on help from her mother, because the school knows about Ana's problem.

Rosse Mary is a very responsible woman, very hardworking, and dedicated to her children. Her dream is for her three children to finish university and be able to reach for a better future. She gives them all she has both economically and spiritually to teach them to be good people.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grocieries

loans.name: Las Ovejitas Group

texts.en:
Indhira is the coordinator of her group, Las Ovejitas (The little lambs), and her story is typical of her group members and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. The group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. Indhira is twenty years old and makes her home here in a simple structure with her mother and father.

Indhira is excited to be taking out her first loan with Esperanza and at the opportunity to grow her business with capital at low interest. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a beauty salon by purchasing a hair dryer. She will use the profits to invest in herself by continuing her university studies and saving towards some day owning her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to buy a hair dryer

loans.name: Chandrani

texts.en:
Chandrani is a 34-year-old married woman living in Hikkaduwa, Sri Lanka, with her husband and two children. Chandrani's husband drove a three-wheeler taxi, but the income was not sufficient to support the family, so together they have started a new business consisting of a rental equipment shop.  Since starting this rental shop, the family income has increased but they are seeking further capital to help expand. Chandrani and her family are very caring people and always try to help others in the community when possible.

Chandrani has requested a 20,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to purchase different types of sound equipment for the rental shop. Ultimately, with their increased income, they hope to renovate their house.  

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase sound equipment

loans.name: Ghafooran's Group

texts.en:
Ghafooran is from the city of Arifwala, in Pakistan. She is married with two children, both in kindergarten. She owns and operates a decorative embroidery business. She receives orders from the cloth shops and makes a profit. She uses her income to pay for the utilities.

Her husband's name is B. A. and he operates a fruit-selling business. He purchases fruits from the fruit markets and supplies to the fruit shops. To fulfill the orders of his customers, he is need of capital so he will maintain his customers and earn well.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Ramota

texts.en:
Ramota, 40,  is married with three children. She sells foodstuffs like yams, beans, peppers, tomatoes, and smoked fish in her shop in Lagos. She is very happy because she loves the business which she has been in since childhood. She has been a member of LAPO microfinance for some years.

Ramota is very enthusiastic about the success of her business and that of her family. She hopes for the loan of NGN 50,000 to buy more foodstuffs in bulk to sell. She hopes to pay back her loan by the due date. She says thanks to LAPO and Kiva for their initiative.

loans.use: To  purchase more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is married with two children. Both of her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she stays with four people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Rehema takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include rent, medication, school fees and feeding the family. Rehema owns a shop selling second hand clothing. Besides this clothing business, she also sells soft drinks like sodas and passion fruits.  She works seven days a week. Rehema receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Rehema has been in this business for four years and her business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for a few years servicing her 12th loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more bales of second hand clothes, crates of soda and passion fruits. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start going directly to Mombasa for second hand clothes. She joined MCDT because she wanted to work with women.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, soda and passion fruit

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: Mariée à BESSOU Paulin, un boulanger, et mère de trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés, M. Christine est née en 1952 à Azowlissè au Bénin. Il y a environ 14 ans que Christine vit à Lokokoukoumè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Christine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assume les charges familiales. En effet, pour aider son mari, Christine mène comme activité principale, la vente de bouillie de maïs, de façon ambulante. De manière secondaire, Christine vend également des beignets. Christine effectue l’achat de ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Christine exerce son activité depuis environ 7 ans mais elle n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Christine est une cliente fidèle de ALIDé car ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. La raison qui l’a poussé à solliciter un quatrième prêt est le souci de renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
Married to Paulin Bessou, a baker, and mother of three children some of whom are educated, Christine M. was born in 1952 in Azowlissè in Bénin. About 14 years ago, Christine lived in Lokokoukoumè in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Christine lives together with her husband and children. The couple takes on the family's responsibilities. In fact, to help her husband, Christine sells corn porridge from a moving cart. On a less frequent basis, she also sells beignets. Christine makes her purchases in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She has done this work for about seven years. She never went to school. Christine is a faithful client of ALIDé, having already benefited from three loans which she repaid in full. She is asking for a fourth loan to strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, sugar, and corn flour

loans.name: Oshilawathi

texts.en:
Oshilawathi is a 58-year-old widow living in Kekanadura, Matara, with her son, who is a doctor. Since her husband died, Oshilawathi has been managing her business by herself, which consists of cultivating a cinnamon garden. She devotes her full effort towards cultivating her cinnamon garden, step by step, and uses the income to help support herself. She has managed her business for two or three years by herself. In her business, she works hard and enjoys the benefits of favorable weather for cinnamon gardening and high quality land for cultivation.

Oshilawathi has asked for a 20,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to to pay labor costs and to purchase chemicals for her cinnamon garden. 

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy chemicals for a cinnamon garden

loans.name: Olalekan

texts.en:
Olalekan sells medicines at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to own a maternity in the future. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more medicines to sell. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction he has with his customers.

Olalekan is 42 years old and married with four children. His eldest child is 18 years old. His children are doing well in school. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen, 35, lives with her family in a city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She and her family live together in a three-room house. She and her family have been living together for the past 18 years. 

Her husband operates a grocery shop at a local market. He purchases the products from various places at wholesale prices and resells them for a profit. He has been operating this business since 2005. He has been planning to diversify his grocery shop into a store in the future. He has good communication skills and he is a very hardworking person. 

Nasreen also operates a clothes-sewing business. She receives orders from the community and earns a profit from it. They both use their income to complete the needs of the family. 

Currently, she is requesting a loan to purchase food products, including biscuits, sugar and lentils, to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a store.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Neetha

texts.en:
Neetha is a 37-year-old married woman living in Kekanadura, Matara, with her husband, four children and her mother. The family consists of three sons and a daughter. Two sons are working while the other son is studying. Her daughter is married.

Neetha has a business selling vegetables from a shop in her town. Her brother is also a partner in her business. They started this business in 2005. When her brother goes to buy vegetables for the shop, she works in the shop.

Neetha has asked for a 60,000 Sri Lankan rupee loan from BRAC Sri Lanka in order to further develop the vegetable business. Neetha is honest and careful in her business. She hopes to provide a nutritious diet to her family through the additional income from the business.

loans.use: To improve a vegetable business

loans.name: Minerva Mirabal 3,4 Group

texts.en:
Lorenza is the coordinator of her group "Minerva Mirabal" (named after one of the legendary Mirabal sisters who resisted and were killed by the dictator Trujillo). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Lorenza is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling bacon by purchasing 200 lb of meat as well as a freezer in which to store it. She will use the profits to invest in education and food for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy meat

loans.name: Sabanalamarino Unidos 4 Group

texts.en: Evelyn, 41, is a borrower who lives in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Sabanalamarino ("Sabana the Sailor") and her story is representative of other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International. Evelyn is a single mother who lives with her three children in Hato Mayor, a small rural town in the heart of the agricultural east in the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to health care among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Evelyn has a successful small business selling new clothing to her friends and those in her community. With this loan, she plans to purchase new clothing for resale. This is Evelyn’s fourth loan with Esperanza International; in a year and a half, she has been able to more than double her loan size, a true testament to her hard work. With continued profits, Evelyn hopes to keep the growth of her business going. Evelyn’s profits have already improved her family’s living conditions, and she looks forward to continuing that trend. The added income has also helped secure a good education for her children and buy supplies for their schooling. Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. There are over 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for your loan to Evelyn and the Sabanalamarino group!

loans.use: To buy new clothing for resale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is widowed with nine children. Four of her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Jane takes care of her grandchildren. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Jane owns a stall selling fruits and vegetables in Kitawuluzi. Besides this vegetable business, she also sells weaving work (including mats and tablecloths) and foodstuffs at her stall.  She works seven days a week. Jane receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Jane has been in this business for 26 years and her business challenges include seasonality. She has been with MCDT for a few years, servicing her third loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying more baskets of fruits and vegetables and meters of cloth for weaving tablecloths. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and get money to construct her own house. She joined MCDT because she could access loans with no collateral with trusted women.

loans.use: To buy fruits, vegetables and fabric

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is 33 years old and married with three children, ages 2, 4 and 7. Innocent's wife is a farmer. Even though this activity does not bring in more money, it is helpful for the family. Both of them work hard in order to provide all the basic needs of their family. Innocent himself has chosen to be a businessman simply because it is more profitable than agriculture. Innocent is seasoned in this career. This is his fifth successful year in business. His shop is open from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening, every day except on Sunday.

Innocent is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing his business and resolving some family problems such as school fees for his children and other needs like good quality food. This loan will be helpful for his family and for his community, who will be satisfied by the products from his shop.

loans.use: To expand his business and for school fees, etc.

loans.name: Olukayode

texts.en: Olukayode has a bore hole and tank that he uses to store and sell water at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to expand his business. The demand for his water is high because he is the only person with a bore hole in his community. He needs a loan in the amount of NGN70,000 to purchase more materials such as a tank and a pumping machine to boost his business. He is 48 years old, married, and has 3 children. His wife also works to support their home. His children are excelling in school and, as a father, this gives him joy. He is an honest and hard working man. He says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to boost his water business.

loans.name: Norah Esther

texts.es:
La señorita Norah Esther M. Orosco tiene 18 años y actualmente vive en Cochabamba en la zona sur, en una Zona conocida como Aziru marca. Ella es soltera y vive actualmente con su mama. 

Norah  es productora de leche cruda, la cual después vende a una empresa que elabora diferentes productos lácteos. Norah se dedica a la producción de leche cruda hace mas de 2 años, en realidad ella se hace cargo también porque su mama ya es mayor de edad y no puede con el manejo del ganado lechero.

Norah solicita el crédito para poder comprar más vacas lecheras y así poder incrementar sus ingresos y poder agrandar el número de vacas de su madre. El mayor sueño de Norah es poder incrementar su producción de leche y sus ingresos de forma que pueda ayudar a su mama a vivir mejor y ella poder mejorar su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Norah Esther M. Orosco is 18 years old and lives in Cochabamba in the southern zone, known as Aziru marca. She is single and lives with her mother.

Norah produces raw milk which she then sells to a company that makes different dairy products. She has doing this for more than two years now and really takes charge of the business since her mother is advanced in years and cannot manage the dairy cows.

Norah is asking for a loan to buy more dairy cows and increase her income and increase the number of her mother's cows too. Norah's main goal is to increase her production of milk and earnings so that she can help her mother live a better life and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy dairy cows

loans.name: Jemilat

texts.en: Jemilat sells drinks and sachet water to make a living. She hopes to make her businesses more sustainable. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN70,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She is 45 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Deysi Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz tiene 30 años y tiene una hija llamada Micaela que tiene 6 años, ella es una madre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a su hija. 

Beatriz tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes que esta ubica en la av.  Mainique de la ciudad de Urubamba, ella empieza su actividad del hogar a las 6 de la mañana cuando por ejemplo preparara desayuno para su hija y para su esposo, ella después se va a trabajar al negocio y ella también alquila carros. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo.

Beatriz pertenece al banco comunal “TERCER MILENIO” de la Asociación Arariwa. Su primer crédito de la socia fue de 100 dólares de las cuales invirtió en su negocio. Actualmente, la socia requiere el préstamo para hacer mantenimientos de los carros. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Beatriz, 30, has a 6-year-old daughter named, Micaela. Beatriz is a responsible mother who always seeks ways to get ahead through her own efforts and provide her daughter with a better future. Beatriz has a small grocery store located on Mainique Avenue in Urubamba. She starts her household chores at 6am preparing breakfast for her daughter and husband. She then goes to work at her store. She also leases cars. She has been in this line of work for several years now and does well thanks to the efforts she puts into her work. Beatriz is a member of Asociación Arariwa's "TERCER MILENIO" (Third Millenium) communal bank. Her first, 100 dollar, loan was invested in her business. Currently, she needs funding to service her vehicles. She is grateful for the opportunity given to her through this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For vehicle maintenance.

loans.name: Unidos Por El Progreso 4 Group

texts.en:
Vicente, 40, is a borrower who lives in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. He is the coordinator for his group, Unidos Por El Progreso (United for Progress), and his story is representative of those in his group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International, a Kiva partner.

Vicente lives with his wife and two children in a simple home in Hato Mayor, a small rural town in the agricultural east of the Dominican Republic. Life in rural areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with) and inadequate access to health care, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Vicente runs a successful small business selling used clothing. With this loan, he will by “ropa de paca,” or packs of used clothing, which he will then organize and sell to those in his community.

This is Vicente’s second loan with Esperanza International. With continued profits, Vicente hopes to continue the growth of his business. He hopes that his additional income will continue helping him finish the construction of his house. A typical home is built in stages. As money becomes available, you add a room, a bathroom or other parts of the home. Vicente will build using cement blocks, a far superior material than traditional wood or sheet-metal siding. With your loan, Vicente will be well on his way to fulfilling this dream for his family’s home.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have over 8,500 active associates in 11 offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Vicente and the Unidos Por El Progreso group!

loans.use: Packs of used clothing for resale

loans.name: Rasoolan's Group

texts.en:
Rasoolan is a citizen of a city in Pakistan named Arifwala. She lives with her family in a three-room house. She has given birth to two sons and both are not of school going age yet. She stays at home and takes care of the family and does domestic chores. 
Her husband’s name is M. S.. He operates a clothes-selling business. He travels to different cities, such as Lahore & Faisalabad, for purchasing. He selected these cities because of their new designs and great quality clothes and most importantly, they are cheap in rates too. He sells his clothes to the clothing markets and earns a good profit. 
Rasoolan is requesting a loan to buy seasonal clothes to expand her husband’s clothes selling business.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes selling business.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is divorced with four children. All her children go to school. She owns a four-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Harriet doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Harriet owns a retail shop selling film, camera batteries and stationery. She works seven days a week. Harriet receives at least 10 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Harriet has been in this business for eight years and her business challenges include seasonality.  Harriet has been with MCDT for seven years, servicing her seventh loan.  She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying film, camera batteries, stationery (black books, pens and envelopes).  She hopes to see her business grow bigger and relocate to Mengo. She joined MCDT because she could access loans easily after a group consensus.

loans.use: To buy more camera batteries, film and stationery.

loans.name: Muyibat

texts.en: Muyibat sells food items to make a living. She hopes to increase her profit in her business. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN40,000 to purchase more food items to sell. She is 50 years old, married, and has  4 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more food items to sell.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel tiene 50  años, es casada y es una madre responsable que busca a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. Su esposo trabaja como albañil así de esta manera apoya al ingreso económico de la familia.    

Isabel alterna sus actividades del hogar con su pequeño negocio de venta de leña, ella también brinda servicios domésticos para los hermanos de la congregación “La Salle” de Urubamba. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo.

Isabel pertenece al banco comunal “TERCER MILENIO” de la Asociación Arariwa. Su primer crédito de la socia fue de 100 dólares de las cuales invirtió en su negocio. Actualmente, la socia requiere el préstamo para comprar leña. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Isabel is 50 years old, is married, and is a responsible mother who in every moment seeks opportunities to get ahead and through her daily efforts to give her children a better future. Her husband works as a builder to support the family financially. Isabel alternates her household activities with her small business selling firewood. She also works as a housekeeper for the brothers of the La Salle congregation of Urubamba. She has been in business for several years now, and it has gone very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into her work. Isabel belongs to the "Tercer Milenio" (Third Milennium) communal bank of Asociación Arariwa. Her first loan was for $100, which she invested in her business. She needs this loan to buy firewood. Isabel is grateful for this opportunity and promises to pay off the loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Isabel needs this loan to buy firewood.

loans.name: Nuevo Renacer 4 Group

texts.en:
Francisca is the coordinator of Nuevo Renacer (New Rebirth), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients in general. Many of these clients have recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband.

Francisca is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and expanded her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of selling cleaning products by purchasing 12 boxes of household cleaner. She will use the profits to invest in her business by saving towards purchasing a vehicle in which to transport her goods. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Cleaning products to sell.

loans.name: Raphatou

texts.fr: A. Raphatou est née en 1990 à Lomé, capitale économique du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin.  Raphatou vit à Adogléta, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Raphatou est célibataire sans enfants. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Raphatou mène comme activité principale la vente de gâteaux à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Raphatou vend également de la bouillie de maïs. Raphatou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Raphatou n’a pas fréquenté l’école mais cela fait bientôt cinq ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. ALIDé a déjà accordé un prêt à Raphatou, prêt qui a été bien remboursé. Raphatou sollicite un deuxième crédit afin de renforcer son activité et se faire plus de revenus pour acheter une parcelle.
texts.en:
Raphatou A. was born in 1990 in Lomé, the economic capital of Togo, a country bordering Bénin. Raphatou is single and has no children. To meet her needs, she sells cakes from her home. She also sometimes sells corn porridge. Raphatou stocks up on supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She never went to school but has done this work for close to five years. ALIDé has already given Raphatou one loan, a loan which she repaid in full. Raphatou is asking for a second loan in order to strengthen her business and make more profits to buy a plot of land.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, oil and sugar

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann has a beauty salon where she makes a living selling hair extensions and providing lovely hair styles for her customers. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN50,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She is 42 years old, married, and has 3 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell.

loans.name: Trifonia

texts.es:
La señora Trifonia tiene 37  años está casada y tiene 4 hijos de (13,10 y 6) años y por ultimo tiene un bebe de 1 mes, son una familia  de escasos recursos económicos ya que actualmente no tienen una casa propia  viven en la casa de su madre en la cual se encuentran muy incómodos porque solo disponen de 2 habitaciones.

Doña Trifonia vive en la ciudad de Cochabamba en la localidad de chaupi suyo, su principal actividad es la producción de la leche cruda, actualmente cuenta con 3 cabezas de ganado lechero en producción, cuyo producto entrega a una empresa que se dedica a la elaboración de productos lácteos, como se puede ver ella apenas empieza con dicha actividad, el esposo se dedica a la agricultura produciendo papa, maíz, haba y zanahoria.

El préstamo será destinado para la compra de una cabeza de ganado lechero para que de esta manera pueda incrementar la cantidad producida de leche, con lo cual incrementara su nivel de ingresos. Entre sus sueños y metas de doña Trifonia es aumentar la cantidad de cabezas de ganado lechero y tener una pequeña granja de por lo menos 20 cabezas de ganado lechero. Pero su meta más importante es construir su casa propia en el terreno que le heredo sus padres, con habitaciones para cada uno de sus hijos y de esta manera estar cómodos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Trifonia is 37 years old, married and has 4 children of 13, 10 and 6 years of age and a one month old infant. They are a family with scarce financial resources. They do not own a home and live in her mother's house, where they are very uncomfortable because they have only two rooms. Mrs. Trifonia lives in the city of Cochabamba in the area of Chaupi Suyo. Her main activity is the production of milk. she currently has 3 heads of of milk cattle. She takes her products to a processing company dedicated to dairy products. She has started this activity only recently. Her husband works in farming, producing potatoes, corn, beans and carrots. The loan is for the purchase of a milk cow because in this way she can increase the quantity of milk that she produces and increase her income. Among the hopes and goals of doña Trifonia is to increase the number of heads of milk cattle and have a small farm with at least 20 milk cows. Her most important goal, however, is to build their own house on the land that she inherited from her parents, with rooms for each one of her children, and this way be more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a milk cow.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en: Teddy is married with school going children.  She rents a two roomed house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Teddy take care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Teddy owns a bar selling all types of drinks in Nakulabye. She works seven days a week. Teddy receives at least for 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people on retail. Teddy has been in this business for long (ie seven years)and her business challenges include thieves and defaulters. She has been with MCDT for years and has been paying her loan promptly.  She wants to use this loan to increase on her stock by buying more crates of beer and jerry cans of local brew. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and own big bar . She joined MCDT because she could access loans easily..

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Guillermo José

texts.es:
El Señor Guillermo José G. H., tiene 65 años de edad vive en el Barrio Laureles norte, es soltero y tiene dos hijos pero no dependen económicamente de él, todos sus hijos son mayores de edad y uno está en el exterior del país, él es jubilado pero su profesión es técnico de  cocina.

Dentro de sus principales necesidades actualmente esta la reconstruccion de su porche, el credito lo ocuparia para la comprad e materiales de construccion con el objeto de realizar las edificaciones, espera se le brinde un apoyo economico para habitar sus dias en un lugar mas comodo y seguro.
texts.en:
Mr. Guillermo José G. H. is 65 years old. He lives in the Barrio Laureles north. He is single and has two children but they do not depend on him financially. His children are adults and one is abroad. He is retired but his profession is that of a kitchen technician. Among his main needs at present is the reconstruction of his porch. He would use the loan to purchase construction materiales with the purpose of undertaking the construction. He hopes you offer him financial support in order to spend his days in a more comfortable and safer place.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Reconstruction of his home's porch

loans.name: Los Pinos Group

texts.es:
El Grupo Solidario LOS PINOS conformado por 3 integrantes las Sras. Carmen, Edith, Maria las tres integrantes son oriundos de santa cruz localidad la guardia y cuentan con el negocio de venta de comida hace 12 años en el mercado central la guardia. 

SLa Sra. Edith se dedica a la  venta de desayuno hace 11 años en el mercado central la guardia, la Sra Edith tiene 4 hijos a su cargo la señora es casada pero actualmente esta separada,  pero aun con esta separacion la señora ha logrado salir adelante y con el credito que le otorgo emprender podra refaccionar y contruir su casita aun asi la señora tiene el sueño de engrandecer su negocio de venta de postres y masitas. 
                                                                                                                 la Sra. Carmen tiene 4 Hijos a su poder y tiene su concubino(Que viven juntos sin estar casados)con el señor Carlos  que se dedica al transporte. El credito que le otorgo emprender podra construir 2 cuartos,  la señora tiene el sueño de tener un restaurant muy grande y muy conocido. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                               La Sra. Maria Cuenta con 2 Hijos a su poder y tiene su concubino el señor Aquilino que se dedica al transporte  el credito que le otorgo emprender fue para la construccion y refaccion de su casa,la señora tiene un sueño de tener una heladeria en la localidad de la guardia.

Las tres integrantes estan agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The "Los Pinos" Group is made up of three members: Carmen, Edith, and Maria. The three members are natives of La Guardia, near Santa Cruz, and for twelve years have run their food sales businesses in the La Guardia central market. Edith has been selling breakfast in the La Guardia central market for 11 years. Edith has four children. She is married but is currently separated, but even with this separation she has managed to keep going, and with the loan Emprender gave her, she will be able to refurbish and build her little house. This lady dreams of expanding her business selling desserts and pastries. Carmen has four children and lives with her partner Carlos, who works in transportation. With the loan Emprender gave her, she will be able to build two rooms. This lady dreams of having a large, well-known restaurant. Maria has two children and lives with her partner Aquilino, who works in transportation. The loan Emprender gave her was for construction and refurbishment of her house. This lady dreams of having an ice cream store in La Guardia. All three members are grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence shown in them with the granting of this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Home construction and refurbishment

loans.name: Dasola

texts.en: Dasola sells engine oil to make a living. With this business, she hopes to make more profits. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN40,000 to purchase more engine oil to sell. She is 40 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her children are still young and they attend school. Her husband also works to support their home. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more engine oil to sell.

loans.name: Mujeres En Accion 3,5 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator of her group Mujeres en Accion (Women in Accion), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients in general. Many of these clienst have recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo, an area where crime is rampant and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and two children.

Maria is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a beauty salon by investing in four lines of hair products to sell to her clients. She will use the profits to purchase the necessary items to make her newly purchased house a home (plates, chairs, etc.). She thanks you all for your support

loans.use: Hair products to sell in her beauty salon.

loans.name: Félicienne

texts.fr: S. Félicienne est née en 1978 à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-podji, au Bénin. Félicienne vit depuis 14 ans à Agblangandan. Félicienne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Mariée à HOUNGA Blaise, un revendeur, Félicienne est mère de deux enfants dont un seul est scolarisé. Le couple vit ensemble avec ses enfants. Félicienne et son mari supportent ensemble les charges de la famille. Pour aider son mari, Félicienne vend des produits cosmétiques (lotions pour le visage,  crèmes, pommades etc.) et des tissus de façon ambulante. Félicienne s’approvisionne à Lomé, capitale économique du Togo, pays voisin du Bénin. Il y a cinq ans que Félicienne exerce son activité. Félicienne a déjà obtenu un prêt chez ALIDé, prêt qui a été bien remboursé. Félicienne désire obtenir un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son stock afin d’être à l’abri d’une pénurie.
texts.en:
Félicienne Sognibe was born in 1978 in Agblangandan, in the commune of Sèmè-podji in Benin. She has been living in Agblangandan for 14 years. She never attended school. Félicienne is married to Blaise Hounga, a vendor, and is the mother of two children, one of whom goes to school. The couple live together with the children. Félicienne and her husband share the responsibility of providing for the family needs. In order to help her husband, Félicienne sells cosmetic produts (face lotions, cremes, ointments etc) and fabrics as a street vendor. She buys her stock in Lomé, the economic capital of Togo, Benin's neighboring country. She has been in this business for five years. Félicienne already had one loan from ALIDé, which she duly repaid. She is seeking a second loan in order to boost her merchandise stock and avoid shortages.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics and cosmetics (face lotions, cremes, ointments etc) for resale

loans.name: Zuleida Jhaira

texts.es:
Zuleida tiene 28 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene una hija de 3 años de edad, vive en casa de su familia, ubicada en el distrito de Monsefú, más conocido en la región como la Ciudad de las Flores. Es un distrito bastante conocido en la región Lambayeque por sus festividades religiosas, la mayor parte de sus habitantes se dedican al cultivo de arroz, de flores, a la artesanía y al comercio.

Se dedica desde hace más de ocho años a la venta de pescado salado en un puesto ubicado en los interiores del mercado Modelo (el principal mercado de la ciudad de Chiclayo). Este mercado es un centro de abastos con bastante afluencia de público, allí se expenden todo tipo de artículos de primera necesidad, verduras, carnes, prendas de vestir, abarrotes, ferreteria y otros. Cuenta con una antigüedad de mas de 50 años y en el se concentran la mayor parte de los negocios de la ciudad de Chiclayo, tanto grandes como pequeños debido a su céntrica ubicación.

Este negocio es la única fuente de ingreso con la que sostiene a su hija y apoya a su familia con los gastos familiares. Zuleida se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de más pescado fresco para procesarlo y venderlo, ya que están próximas las celebraciones de Semana Santa, dias en los cuales el consumo de pescado salado es masivo y de mayor demanda, por lo que es necesario su compra con anticipación.

Ella es una mujer luchadora, entregada a su trabajo y a su familia. Ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Zuleida is 28 years old. She is a single mother and has a three year old daughter. She lives in her family's home, located the district of Monsefú, better known as the City of Flowers. It is a district that is very well known in the Lambayeque region because of its religious festivales. Most of its residents work in growing rice and flowers and in handicrafts and trade. For more than 8 years, she has been selling salted fish in a stall located inside the Modelo market (the main market of the city of Chiclayo). This market is a supply center with a large number of people. All types of basic items are offered there: vegetables, clothing, groceries, hardware, and more. It is more than 50 years old and most of the businesses of the city of Chiclayo are there, large and small, due to its central location. This business is the only source of income that supports her daughter and it helps her family with the family expenses. Zuleida is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles that she is planning on investing in buying more fresh fish to process and sell. Holy Week is coming, and during that time the consumption of salted fish is massive and in high demand. This is why she must make the purchase ahead of time. She is fighter, dedicated to her work and family. She has worked with our institution and has shown herself to always be punctual and responsible in making her payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to process and sell.

loans.name: Orlando De Jesus

texts.es: Don Orlando de Jesús R. Hernández, vive en San Ramón  una comunidad que queda a 20 km de Condega, el tiene una propiedad donde se dedica a las actividades de trabajo de campo como es la agricultura y la ganadería como pequeño productor. Este cliente utilizara el crédito para la compra de 3 terneros para desarrollarlos y después venderlos, con esto él quiere una vez que estos terneros adquieran un mayor peso después venderlos y tener otro ingreso ya que el solo tiene ingresos en épocas de invierno provenientes de la cosecha de granos básicos, este cliente inicio su actividad de trabajo sembrando únicamente granos básicos frijol y maíz con la venta de estos granos el comenzó comprando un torete para desarrollo y una vez este adquirió un mayor peso la vendió a un mejor precio del que lo adquirió. Don Orlando se dedica a esta actividad de trabajo agropecuario cultiva granos básicos frijol y maíz en épocas de invierno y en tiempo de verano el compra y vende ganado para tener otro ingreso. Este cliente  todo el tiempo se ha dedicado a esta actividad de trabajo agrícola y ahora a este rubro o sector ganadero como pequeño productor. Con este crédito el espera tener una forma de trabajo todo el año y ala ves tener otra alternativa que le genere ingresos en épocas de verano donde él no tiene ingresos provenientes de la cosecha, Don Orlando con estos financiamientos ha venido mejorando  su actividad de trabajo, esto le ha permitido mejorar sus ingresos que le permiten sufragar los gastos de su familia y mejorar su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Orlando de Jesús R. Hernández lives in San Ramón, a community located 20 kilometers from Condega. He has a property where he does field work like farming. He also raises some livestock. He will use the loan to buy three calves to raise and later sell. Once the calves have gained weight, he sells them to get another income. His only income comes in the winter season from the harvest of basic grains. He started this work activity by only planting beans and corn. When he sold these grains he bought a small bull to raise. Once it gained weight, he sold it for a higher price than he had paid for it. Orlando works by cultivating beans and corn in the winter time. In the summer, he buys livestock to sell for another income. He has always worked in farming. He now also works as a small producer of livestock. He hopes that with this loan he will have a way to work year round. At the same time, he will have an alternative way to generate income in the summer. That is when he does not have income from the harvest. Orlando has been improving his work with the loans. The loan has allowed him to improve his income. It also allows him to pay family expenses and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy three calves

loans.name: Aderoju

texts.en:
Aderoju sells medicine for a living. She loves her business because of the opportunity it gives her to interact with her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become larger and more profitable. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more medications to sell. Aderoju is 32 years old and married, with 2 children. Her children are still young and they attend school. Her husband also works to support their home. 

Aderoju says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Alabanza De Cristo 4 Group

texts.en:
Madeline, 23, lives in Santiago, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Alabanza de Cristo (Praise for Christ), and her story is representative of those in her group and other Dominican and Haitian borrowers at Esperanza International.

Madeline lives with her husband in a simple home in Santiago, the second-largest city in the Dominican Republic. Life in urban areas of the Dominican Republic can be rough, with overcrowding, no potable running water, frequent power outages (if one has power to begin with), and inadequate access to health care, among other dangers. Despite these difficulties, Madeline runs a successful small business selling items from a small street cart. With this loan, she will purchase clothing, shoes, and perfumes to sell at a small markup.

This is Madeline’s first loan with Esperanza International. With her new access to capital, Madeline hopes to continue the growth of her business. Her dream is to one D. have her own home where she can raise a family with security. Madeline hopes to continue taking out loans with Esperanza after she successfully repays her first. She hopes to have children someD., and her confidence in providing a good life for her children is very high after finding financial security through her loans and her business.

Esperanza International seeks to free children and their families from poverty through initiatives that generate income, education and health, restoring self-worth and dignity to those who have lost hope. We have more than 8,500 active associates in eleven offices in the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Thank you for lending to Madeline and the Alabanza de Cristo group!

loans.use: Clothing, shoes, and perfume for resale

loans.name: Leokadiya

texts.en: Leokadiya is married with six children and all her children go to school. She owns a four-room house where she stays with three people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Leokadiya takes care of additional family members. The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family. Leokadiya owns a bar selling all types of local brew, wines and local gin in Kawempe kilokole. She works seven days a week. Leokadiya receives at least 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people at retail. Leokadiya has been in this business for 10 years. Prior to this business, she was a poultry farmer. Her business challenges include seasonality and the rainy season .  Leokadiya has been with MCDT for seven years. She wants to use this loan to increase her stock by buying jerrycans of local brew and boxes of local gin. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to open a branch in Bwaise.

loans.use: To buy more beer and local gin

loans.name: Mujeres Valientes 1,2,3 Group

texts.en:
Shely is the coordinator of her group Muejres Valientes (Valiant Women). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally. Many of Esperanza's Dominican Republic clients recently emigrated from Haiti. Shely's group is located in Puerto Plata, a coastal town where the economy is based around tourism, and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and seven children.

Shely is excited to be taking her seventh loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. Shely sells used clothing, and she plans to use this loan to purchase large packages of used clothing from sources such as the Salvation Army in the United States.  She will then resell the clothes, using the profits to support her family by providing basic necessities for her children and finishing the construction of her home. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy packages of used clothing to sell

loans.name: Juan Lorenzo

texts.es:
Juan tiene 24 años de edad, es soltero y vive en casa de su padre junto a su hermana menor, su madre es fallecida. Su vivienda está situada en la ciudad de Ferreñafe, zona bastante conocida dentro de la región Lambayeque por sus comidas típicas, la mayor parte de sus habitantes se dedican al comercio y a la siembra de arroz.

Desde hace más de tres años se dedica a la venta de carne de pollo y de otras aves en el mercado central de Ferreñafe. Este mercado es un centro de abastos con bastante afluencia de publico, allí se expenden a la población ferreñafana toda variedad de artículos desde verduras, carnes, prendas de vestir, abarrotes, ferretería y otros. Lleva funcionando 40 años aproximandamente.

Juan es una persona bastante conocida en el mercado debido a que ofrece productos de calidad y un buen trato al cliente, el da todo de si para sacar su negocio adelante ya que es la unica fuente de ingreso económico con la que cuenta. 

Juan se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en hacer mejoras en su vivienda, pues debido a las lluvias, se ha filtrado agua generando deterioro en su estructura. Juan siempre busca el bienestar de su familia, por ello piensa realizar las mejoras necesarias.

Juan es un joven bastante trabajador y entregado a su familia. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Juan is 24 years old. He is single and lives in his father's house with his younger sister. His mother passed away. His housing is located in the city of Ferreñafe, an area very well known within the Lambayeque region because of its traditional food. Most of its residents work in trade and growing rice. For three years he has been selling chicken and other poultry in the central market of Ferreñafe. This market is a supply center with a large number of people. There the Ferreñafen people sell all types of items from vegetables, meats, clothing, groceries, hardware and more. It has been operating for 40 years. Juan is a well known person in the market because he offers quality products and good customer service. He gives everything to get his business ahed since it is the only source of income he has. Juan is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles that he is planning on investing in improving his housing. Due to the rains, water has been leaking, deteriorating the structure. Juan is always looking out for his family's wellbeing and this is why he is planning on undertaking the necesary improvements. Juan is a very hard working young man and dedicated to his family. He has worked before with our institution and has shown himself to be punctual and responsible when it comes to making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expenses to repair housing damaged by rain

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: D. S. Nicole est née en 1981 et vit à Adogléta, un quartier D. Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Nicole est célibataire et mère D. deux enfants tous scolarisés. Nicole a un troisième enfant à sa charge. Nicole vit seule avec ses enfants et subvient seule à leurs divers besoins. Pour assurer la scolarisation D. ses enfants, Nicole vend D. la nourriture et parallèlement à cela, elle commercialise des boissons à son domicile.  Nicole se ravitaille à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Nicole a arrêté les classes au cours primaires mais cela fait déjà 4 ans qu’elle exerce son activité.  Nicole a déjà obtenu un crédit auprès D. ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Dans le souci D. répondre aux nombreuses attentes D. sa clientèle, Nicole sollicite un deuxième près chez ALIDé pour renforcer son commerce.
texts.en:
Nicole D. S. was born in 1981 and lives in Adogléta, a district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Nicole is single and the mother of two children, both in school. Nicole has a third child entrusted to her care. She lives alone with the children and is the sole provider of the household. In order to be able to send her children to school, Nicole sells food and, as a parallel activity, she also sells beverages out of her home. She buys her stock in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Nicole left school while still at the primary level, but she has been running this business for four years now. She already had a loan from ALIDé and duly reimbursed it. Wanting to respond to heavy customer demand, she is seeking a second loan from ALIDé in order to boost her business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing beverages and bags of corn and rice

loans.name: Anastacia Manuela

texts.es: Anastasia es de 38 años de edad, casada con 4 hijos dos varones y dos mujeres, se dedica a tejer cortes típicos, los cuales los vende en el mercado de la localidad, en ASDIR es el segundo crédito que solicita, en el primero demostró puntualidad y responsabilidad, el financiamiento lo necesita para ampliar su capital de trabajo, específicamente para comprar más hilo que le servirá en la tejeduría, con la ayuda del esposo pagaran el crédito.
texts.en:
Anastasia, 38, is married and has four children: two boys and two girls. She weaves traditional clothes that she sells in the local market. This is her second loan with ASDIR; she was responsible and punctual with repaying her first loan. She needs this funding to increase working capital, specifically to buy more thread for her weaving. Her husband will help her repay the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy thread.

loans.name: Esan

texts.en:
Esan is 45 years old, and married, with 5 children.  She sells sarongs and baby items in a shop at her house.  She also sometimes hawks her clothing locally. Esan has been in this business for the past 7 years. She was very happy with the last Kiva loan she took, which allowed her to stock her shop. This made an impact in her business and family life.

Esan is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to enable her buy more sarongs and baby items to sell. She promises to repay her loan by the due date.  With the increased profit, she plans to assist her husband in improving the family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and baby items to sell

loans.name: Julienne A. P.

texts.fr: H. Julienne A. P. est née en 1963 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Julienne A. P. vit à Davatin,un quartier de Sèmè-podji, au Bénin. Mariée à MEVODJO Louis, un vendeur, Julienne A. P. est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Julienne A. P. vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les charges familiales. En effet, pour investir dans la scolarisation de son enfant, Julienne A. P. exerce comme activité principale, la vente de poissons congelés, et de l’huile d’arachide à son domicile. Julienne A. P. s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Julienne A. P. a arrêté les classes au cours primaires, mais exerce son activité depuis 15ans. Julienne A. P. a bénéficié déjà d’un prêt auprès de ALIDé, prêt qui a été bien remboursé. Dans le but de renforcer le stock de ses produits Julienne A. P. désire obtenir un deuxième prêt chez ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Julienne A. P. was born in 1963 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She lives in Davatin, a district of Sèmè-podji, Benin.  Married to MEVODJO Louis, a vendor, she is the mother of one child who is in school.  Julienne A. P. lives together with her husband and child.  Together, the couple are sharing family expenses.  To invest in the education of their child, Julienne A. P. basically has as her main activity a business selling frozen fish and peanut oil out of her home.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She had dropped out of primary school but has been operating her business for fifteen years.  She has already benefited from a loan from ALIDé that she has repaid.  With the goal of boosting her stock of goods, Julienne A. P. would like a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying boxes of frozen fish and some peanut oil

loans.name: Leona Lucia

texts.es: Leona es de 61 años de edad, tuvo cuatro hijo dos varones y dos mujeres todos ya están casados, ella es viuda y se dedica a tejer y vender cortes típicos en el mercado local, en ASDIR es el segundo crédito que solicita, el anterior lo pago con mucha responsabilidad, Doña leona es muy conocida como participativa y colaboradora en su población, a pesar de la edad tiene muchas energías y ganas de superar, necesita el financiamiento apara ampliar su capital de trabajo, específicamente la compra de hilo para su tejeduría.
